questions.text: In a 35-year-old man exhibiting loss of appetite, belching and burning abdominal pain, which of the following anatomical structures is affected?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

The most common location for peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is the duodenal bulb, the first part of the duodenum that receives food from the stomach. The duodenal bulb is particularly susceptible to damage from acidic stomach contents because it is the site of the pylorus, where the stomach empties its contents into the small intestine. 

The pylorus acts as a valve that regulates the flow of stomach contents into the duodenum. When it becomes damaged or weakened, acid can reflux into the duodenal bulb and cause inflammation and ulceration.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option B. Ulcers can also occur in other stomach parts, such as the cardiac region, but it is less common than duodenal ulcers. 

Option C. Ulcers can also occur in other stomach parts, such as the pyloric antrum, but it is less common than duodenal ulcers. 

Option D. The fundus of the stomach, which is the upper part of the stomach that lies above the cardiac region, is typically unaffected by peptic ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical structures is affected in Barrett's esophagus?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
 
In Barrett's esophagus, the normal squamous epithelium of the esophageal mucosa is replaced by columnar epithelium with goblet cells. This change is often the result of chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). 


Incorrect Choices:

Option A. While the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is involved in GERD, Barrett's esophagus does not directly affect it.

Option B. The upper esophageal sphincter (UES) is the muscular ring that separates the esophagus from the pharynx and is unaffected by Barrett's esophagus.

Option D. The esophageal submucosa is the layer of connective tissue beneath the mucosa. While it may be affected by advanced cases of Barrett's esophagus, it is not typically involved in the initial stages of the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a pregnant woman more prone to develop?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Cervical lordosis is the abnormal curvature in the neck. The abnormal curvature means:

  • Presence of excess curvature
  • Curvature running in the opposite direction
  • Movement of curvature to the left
  • Movement of curvature to the right

This condition is most commonly observed in children in their growth stage, pregnant women and adults above the age of 50 years.

In order to expiate the movement of the centre of gravity and posterior shift in body weight, pregnant women are more prone to develop cervical lordosis. Furthermore, a forward pull in the neck can be caused due to the growing foetus and an increase in the size of the breasts during pregnancy.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Horner’s syndrome, also called oculosympathetic palsy, is a brachial plexus disorder that occurs due to disruption in the nerve pathway from one side of the brain to the face and eyes. It may result from other medical conditions such as stroke, spinal cord injury or tumour.

Option B. Lupus is an autoimmune disorder that affects the joints, skin, kidneys, lungs, heart, blood cells and brain. It is an inflammatory disorder that can cause fever, joint pain, rashes and organ damage.

Option D. Marfan syndrome is a genetic disorder in which the body’s connective tissues get affected. People with Marfan syndrome may have abnormally long fingers, crowded teeth, pain in the back, a tall or slender build, experience fatigue, scoliosis and many other symptoms.

questions.text: What is the characteristic histological feature of Hirschsprung disease?

choices.text: Increased number of ganglion cells in the affected area
Lack of ganglion cells in the afflicted area
Fibrosis of the submucosal and myenteric plexuses
Infiltration of eosinophils in the affected area

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition marked by ganglion cell deficiency in the distal colon. The lack of these nerve cells prevents the gut muscles from being stimulated, causing the colon's contents to back up and cause bowel blockages.

Incorrect choices:

Option A is incorrect, as increased ganglion cells would be a normal finding. 

Option C is incorrect, as fibrosis results from chronic inflammation and is not a characteristic feature of Hirschsprung disease. 

Option D is incorrect, as eosinophil infiltration is not a characteristic feature of Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT correct regarding the layers of the embryonic disc?

choices.text: The epiblast develops into the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm germ layers.
The hypoblast plays a role in the yolk sac's development.
The epiblast and hypoblast are formed during the gastrulation stage of embryonic development.
The hypoblast gives rise to the amniotic sac.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
The hypoblast layer does not give rise to the amniotic sac but rather contributes to the formation of the yolk sac. The amniotic sac is formed from the epiblast layer and the extraembryonic mesoderm, which forms the amnion. 
The hypoblast is essential for developing the extraembryonic membranes, including the amnion, chorion, and allantois. These membranes are important for protecting and supporting the developing embryo.
Incorrect Choices:
Option A: The epiblast develops into the ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm germ layers, essential for forming all the major organs and tissues in the body. 
Option B: The hypoblast layer is located below the epiblast and forms the lining of the yolk sac, which provides nutrients to the developing embryo. 
Option C: The epiblast and hypoblast layers are formed during the gastrulation stage of embryonic development. The blastula undergoes a series of cell divisions and rearrangements to form a three-layered embryo.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an internal carotid artery (ICA) branch?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
The vertebral artery is not a branch of the internal carotid artery. It is a major blood vessel that supplies the posterior part of the brain with oxygenated blood. It originates from the subclavian artery and passes through the foramen magnum into the skull, which joins with another artery to form the basilar artery. The vertebral artery gives off several branches, including the anterior spinal artery, posterior spinal artery, and posterior inferior cerebellar artery. These branches supply oxygenated blood to the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebellum.
Incorrect choices: 
Option A: An internal carotid artery branch called the anterior choroidal artery nourishes the posterior limb of the internal capsule, the optic tract, and the choroid plexus of the brain's lateral ventricle with blood. It originates distal to the posterior connecting artery from the internal carotid artery.
Option B: One principal blood channel that carries oxygenated blood to the brain is the middle cerebral artery (MCA). It arises from the internal carotid artery and enters the skull through the lateral sulcus (the Sylvian fissure). The MCA supplies blood to the lateral surface of the cerebral hemispheres, including the primary motor and sensory cortices, the language areas, and parts of the basal ganglia and thalamus.
Option C: The posterior communicating artery (PCoA) is a small blood vessel that connects the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) to the internal carotid artery (ICA) in the circle of Willis, which is an important arterial ring at the base of the brain that provides collateral circulation to the brain. The PCoA maintains blood flow to the posterior part of the brain in case of a blockage or stenosis of the ICA or PCA. It also plays a role in regulating blood pressure and blood flow in the brain.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with a history of chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination, a systolic murmur is heard over the precordium, and electrocardiography (ECG) reveals ST-segment elevation. The patient is diagnosed with acute coronary syndrome and requires emergency cardiac surgery. During the surgical procedure, the surgeon is carefully dissecting the posterior surface of the heart. Which structures would the surgeon encounter while operating on this surface?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Left atrium and left ventricle. The posterior surface of the heart is formed by the left atrium and the left ventricle. The function of left atrium is to receive oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins and pumps it into the left ventricle. The left ventricle is the largest and thickest chamber of the heart and pumps oxygenated blood into systemic circulation. During cardiac surgery, the surgeon would encounter these structures while operating on the posterior surface of the heart.

Incorrect Choice: 

Option A) Left atrium and right ventricle are incorrect because the right ventricle forms part of the anterior surface of the heart, not the posterior surface. The right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation, and its presence is not expected during the dissection of the heart's posterior surface.

Option B) Left ventricle and right atrium is also incorrect because the right atrium forms part of the anterior surface of the heart, not the posterior surface. The right atrium receives deoxygenated blood from the systemic circulation and pumps it into the right ventricle. Its presence is not expected during the dissection of the heart's posterior surface.

Option D) Right atrium and right ventricle is incorrect for the same reasons as option A. The right atrium and ventricle are part of the anterior surface of the heart and would not be encountered during the dissection of the posterior surface.
Incorrect Choices:

questions.text: A 35-year-old overweight female underwent a D & C surgery. The surgery was done in the lithotomy position and was successful. Post-procedure, however, the patient had paralysis of the adductor muscles and numbness in the medial side of the thigh. What could be the possible reason for this complication?

choices.text: Pudendal nerve injury during the procedure.
Obturator nerve injury due to lithotomy positioning
Femoral nerve injury during the procedure
Superficial peroneal nerve injury due to compression during the procedure.

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Due to improper lithotomy positioning, obturator nerve damage can develop after gynaecological procedures. In the lithotomy position, the obturator nerve may get compressed against the inferior side of the pubic ramus at the level of the obturator foramen. According to research, 5 in 1000 patients develop this complication after being in the lithotomy position.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. The pain in pudendal nerve injury is felt over the buttocks and genital region. It is rarely injured during the discussed procedures.

Option C. Femoral nerve is not injured in the D&C procedure; it is the main nerve in the anterior compartment of the thigh. Injury causes palsy of the quadriceps femoris muscle and sensory deficit in the medial thigh and leg.

Option D: Superficial peroneal nerve is related to the neck of the fibula. After supplying both the peronei, the superficial peroneal nerve splits into medial and lateral cutaneous branches to supply the dorsum of the foot. Once the superficial peroneal nerve hits the deep leg fascia, it may become entrapped. At the subtalar joint, its paralysis results in a loss of foot eversion.

questions.text: You are taking an anatomy class for your juniors in the dissection hall regarding the topic of Salivary glands. Which of the following may be a wrong statement regarding the Stenson’s duct?

choices.text: The accessory parotid gland is located below it.
It is commonly about 5 centimetre in length.
It has an oblique course through the buccinator muscle.
It terminates at the vestibule region of the mouth, approximately opposite to the crown of the 2nd upper molar tooth.

questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

The parotid duct is also known as the Stenson’s duct. It runs forwards in a downward direction on the masseter muscle. Here, the accessory parotid gland lies superior to it.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option B. The Stenson’s duct is usually as long as 5 cm. Meanwhile, the duct’s diameter ranges between 1.4 mm and 0.5mm.

Option C. The parotid duct travels diagonally through the buccinator muscle. This may be why the duct does not enlarge when blowing using the muscle.

Option D: The Stenson’s duct travels in the submucosa from the upper 3rd molar teeth towards the direction of the upper second molar tooth.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of atavistic joints?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Atavistic joints are characterized by limited movement, as the fibrous or cartilaginous tissue connecting the two bone ends does not allow for free movement as in a normal joint. These joints structurally resemble fibrous joints and are formed when fractured bones do not heal correctly after a fracture.

Atavistic joints are a type of disease, and its symptoms resemble those of arthritis and include lack of movement, joint clicking, persisting pain, along with redness and fever in some cases.

Incorrect choices:

Option B. Diarthrosis or synovial joints are the joints that have free movement. These joints are characterized by the presence of a joint capsule that encloses the joint cavity and synovial fluid that lubricates the joint. They allow for various movements, such as flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation. Examples of synovial joints include the shoulder, hip, knee, elbow, and ankle joints.

Option C. Synarthrosis or fibrous joints are immobile joints. These joints are characterized by dense fibrous connective tissue that connects the bones, preventing movement. These joints provide stability and support to the bones, protecting vital organs such as the brain.

Option D. Joints may have painful movement due to various conditions or injuries. Arthritis, a condition that causes inflammation of the joints, can lead to painful movement. Injuries such as sprains or strains can cause pain during movement as well. Additionally, conditions such as bursitis, tendonitis, or osteoporosis can cause painful movement in the affected joints.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents with weakness and numbness in his left arm and leg. A CT scan reveals a blockage in the blood vessels supplying the somatosensory area of the brain. Which artery from the list below is most likely to be impacted?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Numbness is the loss of sensation in hands, arms, legs or feet due to a blockage to the blood supply to and from the heart. It means blockage in arteries can result in numbing of areas to which the blocked artery supplies blood. Numbness may occur on either one side of the body or on both sides simultaneously.
The primary arterial supply to the somatic sensory cortex occurs through the anterior and middle cerebral arteries, with the middle cerebral artery supplying blood to most of the region. Hence, blockage in the middle cerebral artery would cause weakness and numbness in the left leg and arm.
Incorrect Choices:
Option B. Blockages in the anterior cerebral artery, which supplies the cerebral hemispheres’ medial surface, including the motor cortex, may cause weakness or paralysis of the legs, but not typically the arms. 
Option C. Blockages in the posterior cerebral artery may cause visual disturbances, resulting in blindness on one visual field side in people.
Option D. Blockages in the basilar artery may affect the brainstem and cerebellum. This may result in patients experiencing facial palsies, dizziness, headache, motor deficits, and/or speech abnormalities like dysarthria.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man was brought to the hospital due to complaints of the unequal pupil of the left eye, blurred vision and inability to sweat normally. An MRI scan reveals damage to the sympathetic trunk. Which of the following is the diagnosis of the doctors for the patient?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

The sympathetic trunk, a part of the sympathetic nervous system, runs from the cranium base to the coccyx bone. The sympathetic trunks comprise two ganglionated nerve trunks through which nerve fibres travel to the superior and inferior spinal nerves than the one they originated from.

Damage to the sympathetic trunk may result in Horner’s syndrome. This disorder occurs as a result of avulsion of the lower brachial plexus. Droopy eyelid or unequal pupil, blurred vision and inability to sweat normally are typical and common symptoms of Horner’s syndrome.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Brachial neuritis or Parsonage-Turner syndrome is a progressive and rare brachial plexus disorder of unknown cause. The disorder’s symptoms include severe shoulder and upper arm pain that gradually changes to weakness, muscle loss and loss of sensation.

Option B. A brachial plexus avulsion is an injury that occurs when a brachial plexus nerve gets completely separated by its roots from the spinal cord. This injury can result in permanent paralysis, weakness and loss of sensation or numbness. 

Option C. In neuropraxia, a brachial plexus nerve is stretched to the point of injury. It is the type of injury; symptoms may either be a burning or a stinging sensation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with swelling around his eyes and in his lower extremities that has been getting worse over the past few weeks. He has also been complaining of abdominal pain and has been urinating more frequently. On examination, he is found to have marked edema around his eyes, legs, and abdomen. His urine dipstick test reveals significant proteinuria. His serum albumin level is found to be low. A renal biopsy is performed and is shown below.
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

The clinical presentation in this scenario is classic for nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by significant proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and edema. 

The renal biopsy findings of diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with no cellular proliferation are typical of minimal change disease, which is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A. Acute glomerulonephritis is characterized by hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It is typically caused by streptococcal infections and is associated with immune complex deposition and inflammation of the glomeruli. The renal biopsy findings in acute glomerulonephritis typically show glomerular inflammation with leukocyte infiltration and proliferation.

Option B: Chronic glomerulonephritis is a progressive renal disease that is characterized by persistent proteinuria, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It is typically caused by autoimmune or infectious processes and is associated with glomerular scarring and fibrosis. The renal biopsy findings in chronic glomerulonephritis typically show glomerular sclerosis and interstitial fibrosis.

Option D: Membranous nephropathy is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with deposition of immune complexes. It typically presents with proteinuria and is associated with autoimmune or infectious processes. The renal biopsy findings in membranous nephropathy typically show subepithelial deposits and thickening of the glomerular basement membrane.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of fever, fatigue, and flu-like symptoms for the past week. She is in her 22nd week of gestation and has not received any prenatal care yet. On further evaluation, it is found that she is positive for torch infections. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Torch infections are a group of infections that can be transmitted from the mother to the fetus during pregnancy. These infections can cause a wide range of clinical symptoms and can result in serious complications in the fetus such as miscarriage, stillbirth, or developmental abnormalities.

In the clinical scenario described above, the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms is cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV is the most common cause of congenital infections, and it can cause symptoms such as fever, fatigue, and flu-like symptoms in pregnant women. Other symptoms of CMV infection can include sore throat, swollen glands, and body aches

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Toxoplasma gondii is a protozoan parasite that can cause a condition known as toxoplasmosis. It is transmitted through ingestion of undercooked or raw meat, contact with cat feces, or through blood transfusions or organ transplants. While it can cause flu-like symptoms in pregnant women, it is usually asymptomatic or may present with mild symptoms such as fever and fatigue. However, in rare cases, it can cause severe complications in the fetus such as hydrocephalus and microcephaly. Since the patient in the scenario presented with symptoms of fever, fatigue, and flu-like symptoms, toxoplasmosis could be a possible cause, but it is not the most likely cause of her symptoms. Therefore, option A is incorrect.

Option B. Rubella virus, also known as German measles, is a viral infection that can cause rash, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in pregnant women. However, it is rare in developed countries due to the widespread use of the rubella vaccine. The patient in the scenario presented with symptoms of fever, fatigue, and flu-like symptoms, which are not specific to rubella virus infection. Moreover, rubella virus infection is not the most common cause of torch infections, and hence, option B is incorrect.

Option D. Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a virus that causes genital herpes and cold sores. It can be transmitted from mother to child during pregnancy and delivery, and can cause serious complications in newborns, including encephalitis and neonatal herpes. In pregnant women, HSV can cause genital lesions, but it is usually asymptomatic. In rare cases, it can cause flu-like symptoms, but this is not a common presentation of HSV infection. Therefore, option D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents for a routine check-up. The child is able to walk, but still falls frequently. He can say a few words like "mama" and "dada", but are not yet forming sentences. On examination, the child is able to stack blocks, but has difficulty drawing basic shapes. Which of the following developmental milestones is the child most likely delayed in?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Fine motor skills refer to a child's ability to use their small muscles to perform tasks such as grasping objects, drawing, and writing. The child in the scenario has difficulty drawing basic shapes, suggesting that they may be delayed in fine motor skills.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A. Gross motor skills refer to a child's ability to use their large muscles to perform tasks such as sitting, crawling, walking, and running. Based on the scenario, the child is able to walk but falls frequently, suggesting that they may be somewhat delayed in gross motor skills, but this is not their primary area of delay.

Option C. Language development refers to a child's ability to understand and use language. The child in the scenario can say a few words, but is not yet forming sentences, suggesting that they may be delayed in language development. However, it is not the primary concern in this case.

Option D. Social and emotional development refers to a child's ability to form relationships with others and regulate their own emotions. The scenario does not provide enough information to determine if the child is delayed in social and emotional development

questions.text: A 32-week gestational age male baby weighing 1.2 kg is born to a mother with poor antenatal care. The baby has a head circumference of 26 cm, length of 38 cm, and an abdominal circumference of 20 cm. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d) Symmetrical intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). IUGR refers to a condition where the fetus fails to reach its genetically determined growth potential. In symmetrical IUGR, all the parameters (head circumference, length, and abdominal circumference) are reduced proportionally, as seen in the given case. Risk factors for IUGR include maternal factors such as poor nutrition, hypertension, smoking, and alcohol intake.

Option a) Appropriate for gestational age (AGA) is incorrect. AGA refers to a baby whose weight is appropriate for their gestational age. These babies have a head circumference, length, and abdominal circumference within the normal range for their gestational age.

Option b) Small for gestational age (SGA) is incorrect. SGA refers to a baby whose weight is below the 10th percentile for their gestational age. In SGA, the head circumference is usually normal or close to normal, while the length and abdominal circumference are reduced.

Option c) Large for gestational age (LGA) is incorrect. LGA refers to a baby whose weight is above the 90th percentile for their gestational age. These babies have a head circumference, length, and abdominal circumference within the normal range or above for their gestational age.

questions.text: A 34-week gestational age baby is born with respiratory distress, tachypnea, and grunting. On physical examination, there is decreased breath sounds and fine crackles heard over the lung fields. The baby is not improving with oxygen therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d) Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). RDS is a common cause of respiratory distress in premature babies, especially those born before 34 weeks of gestation. It is caused by a deficiency of surfactant, which leads to alveolar collapse and decreased lung compliance. The clinical features of RDS include respiratory distress, tachypnea, grunting, and decreased breath sounds. Fine crackles may also be heard over the lung fields. RDS can be diagnosed by a chest X-ray, which shows diffuse bilateral ground-glass opacities.

Option a) Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is incorrect. TTN is a self-limiting condition that occurs in full-term or late-preterm babies due to retained fetal lung fluid. It presents with tachypnea, grunting, and mild respiratory distress that usually resolves within 72 hours. The chest X-ray shows mild perihilar streaking.

Option b) Meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS) is incorrect. MAS occurs when a baby passes meconium into the amniotic fluid and subsequently inhales it into their lungs. It presents with respiratory distress, tachypnea, and cyanosis. The chest X-ray shows patchy infiltrates and hyperinflation.

Option c) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is incorrect. CDH is a rare condition where there is a defect in the diaphragm, allowing abdominal contents to herniate into the thorax. It presents with severe respiratory distress and hypoxemia. The chest X-ray shows herniation of abdominal contents into the thorax.

questions.text: A 2-day-old baby presents with cyanosis, poor feeding, and a loud, single second heart sound. On examination, there is a systolic ejection murmur heard over the left sternal border.. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is d) Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). TOF is a congenital heart defect that consists of four features: a ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It presents with cyanosis, poor feeding, and a loud, single second heart sound. A systolic ejection murmur may be heard over the left sternal border. A chest X-ray shows a "boot-shaped" heart due to the right ventricular hypertrophy.

Option a) Atrial septal defect (ASD) is incorrect. ASD is a congenital heart defect that involves a defect in the atrial septum, allowing blood to flow from the left atrium to the right atrium. It presents with a loud, fixed splitting of the second heart sound and a systolic ejection murmur over the pulmonary valve.

Option b) Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is incorrect. VSD is a congenital heart defect that involves a defect in the ventricular septum, allowing blood to flow from the left ventricle to the right ventricle. It presents with a loud, harsh holosystolic murmur heard over the left sternal border.

Option c) Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is incorrect. PDA is a congenital heart defect that involves a failure of the ductus arteriosus to close after birth, leading to a shunt of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery. It presents with a continuous machinery-like murmur heard over the left upper sternal border.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a white pupil and strabismus in the right eye. Examination reveals a white, spherical mass in the right eye with surrounding retinal detachment. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

The clinical scenario is consistent with the presentation of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is a malignant tumour of the retina that commonly presents with a white pupil (leukocoria) and strabismus in children under the age of 5. 

The white, spherical mass in the right eye with surrounding retinal detachment seen on examination is a classic finding in retinoblastoma.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Retinal detachment can cause vision loss and visual disturbances, but it would not present with a white, spherical mass in the eye. Retinal detachment occurs when the retina separates from the underlying tissue, and it is usually caused by trauma or aging.

Option C. Congenital cataract is a clouding of the lens of the eye that is present at birth or develops during the first year of life. It can cause vision loss and may present with leukocoria, but it would not typically present with a white, spherical mass in the eye. The presence of a mass is more consistent with a tumor such as retinoblastoma.

Option D. Optic nerve glioma is a type of brain tumor that can affect the optic nerve, but it typically presents with gradual vision loss, headache, and other neurological symptoms. It would not present with a white, spherical mass in the eye. Additionally, optic nerve glioma is extremely rare in children under the age of 5, making retinoblastoma a more likely diagnosis in this scenario.

questions.text:
A newborn infant is found to have a defect in the lower spinal region with a sac-like        



 protrusion containing spinal cord and meninges. On further evaluation, it is diagnosed as myelomeningocele. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this infant?

choices.text: Surgical closure of the defect within 24 hours of birth

questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
 
Myelomeningocele, also known as spina bifida cystica, is a type of neural tube defect that occurs during fetal development when the spinal cord and its coverings fail to form properly. This leads to a protrusion of the spinal cord through an opening in the vertebrae, resulting in neurological symptoms.
The most appropriate initial management for a newborn infant with myelomeningocele is surgical closure of the defect within 24 hours of birth to prevent infection and further neurological damage.

Incorrect choices:

Option B. Administration of intravenous antibiotics is not the most appropriate initial management for myelomeningocele. While prophylactic antibiotics may be administered before and after surgery, they are not the primary management for this condition.

Option C. Administration of oral antibiotics is not the most appropriate initial management for myelomeningocele. Prophylactic antibiotics may be administered before and after surgery, but they are not the primary management for this condition.

Option D. Observation and conservative management is not the most appropriate initial management for myelomeningocele. This condition requires prompt surgical closure to prevent infection and further neurological damage.

questions.text: Which of the following types of hyperplasia is not considered a physiological response?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
Hyperplasia can be a physiological or pathological process, depending on the cause and location. Physiological hyperplasia is a normal response to a stimulus, such as hormonal changes or tissue injury, while pathological hyperplasia is an abnormal response that can lead to the development of pre-cancerous or cancerous cells.
Facultative hyperplasia is not a physiological response but is instead a type of abnormal growth that occurs in response to specific stimuli. It is an adaptive response to environmental changes, such as the excessive growth of muscle fibers in athletes or the enlargement of the thyroid gland in response to iodine deficiency.
Incorrect choices:
Option A. Compensatory hyperplasia occurs when the remaining cells of an organ or tissue proliferate and enlarge in response to injury or partial loss of tissue. For example, the liver can regenerate its mass after partial hepatectomy.
Option B. Hormonal hyperplasia occurs as a response to hormonal stimulation, such as the breast enlargement during pregnancy or the uterine lining thickening during the menstrual cycle.
Option C. Pathological hyperplasia occurs as a response to abnormal stimuli, such as chronic irritation or inflammation, and it can lead to the development of pre-cancerous or cancerous cells. For example, the chronic irritation of the bronchial tree can lead to the development of bronchial squamous metaplasia and ultimately lung cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism of reversible cell injury?

choices.text: Formation of mitochondrial permeability transition pores

questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 
Reversible cell injury is a type of cellular damage that can be reversed if the underlying cause is corrected. It occurs due to various factors, such as hypoxia, chemical toxins, and physical agents. 
Mitochondrial permeability transition pores (MPTP) are not a mechanism of reversible cell injury but rather a mechanism of irreversible cell injury. MPTP is a protein complex that is formed in the inner mitochondrial membrane, leading to the loss of the mitochondrial membrane potential and the release of apoptotic factors. This ultimately leads to cell death.
Incorrect choices: 
Option A. Decreased ATP production is one of the key mechanisms of reversible cell injury. ATP is the primary energy source for cellular processes, and decreased ATP production leads to the failure of ion pumps, resulting in the accumulation of sodium and water inside the cell.
Option B. Cellular swelling is another mechanism of reversible cell injury, characterized by the accumulation of water inside the cell due to the failure of ion pumps. This results in the swelling of the cell and disruption of its normal function.
Option D. Impaired protein synthesis is another mechanism of reversible cell injury, where the synthesis of new proteins is reduced due to the inhibition of ribosomes. This results in the impairment of cellular function.

questions.text: Which of the following types of necrosis is characterized by the formation of amorphous eosinophilic debris with no nuclear remnants?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct. 
Necrosis is a type of cell death that occurs due to various factors, such as ischemia, toxins, infections, and physical injury. 
Coagulative necrosis is a type of necrosis that occurs due to ischemia, resulting in the denaturation of proteins and the formation of amorphous eosinophilic debris with no nuclear remnants. The cellular architecture is preserved, giving rise to the term "coagulative" necrosis. It is commonly seen in organs such as the heart, kidney, and liver.
Incorrect choices:
Option B. Liquefactive necrosis is a type of necrosis that occurs due to the action of hydrolytic enzymes, resulting in the liquefaction of the affected tissue. It is commonly seen in the brain due to the action of microglial cells.
Option C. Fat necrosis is a type of necrosis that occurs due to the release of pancreatic lipases, resulting in the breakdown of adipose tissue and the formation of chalky white areas. It is commonly seen in the pancreas and breast.
Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis is a type of necrosis that occurs due to the deposition of immune complexes and fibrin in the walls of blood vessels, resulting in thickening and narrowing of the vessel lumen. It is commonly seen in autoimmune diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus and polyarteritis nodosa.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a painless lump in her left breast that was discovered incidentally during a routine mammogram. Ultrasound examination reveals a well-defined, hypoechoic mass with thin, elongated extensions into the ductal system. Biopsy of the mass confirms the presence of an intraductal papilloma. Which of the following statements is true regarding intraductal papilloma?

choices.text: Sheets of malignant cells with high mitotic activity
Epithelial projections lined by myoepithelial cells
Infiltrative growth pattern with irregular borders

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Intraductal papilloma is a benign tumor that arises from the epithelial cells lining the ducts of the breast. It is composed of composed of branching papillary projections lined by a layer of myoepithelial cells and supported by a fibrovascular core.
The epithelial cells lining the papillae are often arranged in a bilayer or pseudostratified pattern and are surrounded by a layer of myoepithelial cells. Epithelial projections lined by myoepithelial cells is the characteristic feature of intraductal papilloma. 
Incorrect Choices:
Option A. Sheets of malignant cells with high mitotic activity. This feature is not characteristic of intraductal papilloma. Intraductal papillomas are benign tumors that are composed of a mix of epithelial and stromal elements.
Option B. Fibrous stroma with infiltrating lymphocytes. This feature is not characteristic of intraductal papilloma. Intraductal papillomas have a fibrovascular core, but lymphocyte infiltration is not a typical finding.
Option D. Infiltrative growth pattern with irregular borders. This feature is not characteristic of intraductal papilloma. Intraductal papillomas have a well-circumscribed border and are confined to the ductal system of the breast.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents to the orthopedic clinic with a three-month history of persistent right knee pain. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the distal femur and limitation of knee movement. Imaging studies show a destructive lesion in the distal femur with periosteal reaction and soft tissue swelling as seen in image. Biopsy of the lesion shows malignant cells that produce osteoid. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
The clinical presentation and imaging findings are suggestive of a bone tumor. Biopsy of the lesion shows malignant cells that produce osteoid, which is a characteristic feature of osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma also manifest as a periosteal bone reactive response with a poorly defined lytic, sclerotic, or mixed-density lesion.
Incorrect Choices:
Option A. Chondrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the cartilage-forming cells of the bone. It does not produce osteoid and typically presents with pain and swelling that is worse at night.
Option B. Ewing sarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the bone marrow and is characterized by the presence of small round cells. It does not produce osteoid and typically presents with pain and swelling that is worse at night.
Option D. Fibrosarcoma is a malignant tumor that arises from the fibroblast cells of the bone. It does not produce osteoid and typically presents with pain and swelling.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with fatigue, malaise, and intermittent claudication in the upper extremities. On examination, there is a decreased pulse in the right brachial artery, absent radial and ulnar pulses, and a blood pressure difference of > 10 mmHg between the two arms. A CT angiogram shows thickening and stenosis of the subclavian and carotid arteries. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

Takayasu's arteritis is a rare autoimmune disease that affects large vessels, particularly the aorta and its branches. It commonly affects young women and presents with non-specific symptoms such as fatigue, malaise, and fever. 

Claudication, deceased or absent pulses, and blood pressure discrepancies between the arms are common findings on examination. CT angiogram or MRI angiography can show thickening and stenosis of the subclavian and carotid arteries.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Giant cell arteritis is a disease that affects medium and large-sized arteries, most commonly the temporal artery. It presents with headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication. The physical examination may reveal a palpable, tender temporal artery. A biopsy of the temporal artery is diagnostic.

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa is a necrotizing vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries. It presents with fever, weight loss, and myalgias. Skin lesions, peripheral neuropathy, and abdominal pain are other common manifestations. The diagnosis is made by biopsy of an affected artery or aneurysm.

Option C. Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that predominantly affects children under five years of age. It presents with fever, conjunctivitis, oral mucosal changes, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Coronary artery aneurysms are a significant complication of Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with fever, malaise, and chest pain. On examination, a friction rub is heard over the precordium. ECG shows diffuse ST elevation. A biopsy of the heart shows the presence of Aschoff bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Aschoff bodies are histological features of rheumatic heart disease. They are granulomatous nodules that contain lymphocytes, plasma cells, and Anitschkow cells (activated macrophages). These nodules are typically found in the myocardium but can also be present in other organs affected by rheumatic fever. 

Rheumatic fever is a post-streptococcal immune-mediated disease that affects the heart, joints, skin, and central nervous system.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Acute myocardial infarction is caused by the occlusion of a coronary artery, usually due to a thrombus. It presents with chest pain, ECG changes, and elevated cardiac enzymes. Aschoff bodies are not seen in acute myocardial infarction.

Option C. Dilated cardiomyopathy is a disease that causes enlargement and dysfunction of the heart. It can be caused by various factors such as viral infections, alcohol abuse, or genetics. Aschoff bodies are not seen in dilated cardiomyopathy.

Option D. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a genetic disorder that causes the thickening of the heart muscle, especially the interventricular septum. It can cause obstructive symptoms, arrhythmias, and sudden cardiac death. Aschoff bodies are not seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painless, slowly growing mass on her right leg. On examination, the mass is well-circumscribed and mobile. MRI shows a well-defined mass arising from a nerve sheath with no invasion of surrounding tissues. Biopsy of the mass reveals spindle-shaped cells arranged in a palisading pattern. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
 
Schwannomas are benign tumours arising from Schwann cells, which form the myelin sheath around peripheral nerves. They are typically slow-growing, well-circumscribed, and mobile masses that arise from a nerve sheath. 

On histology, they show spindle-shaped cells arranged in a palisading pattern, a characteristic feature. MRI is the imaging modality of choice to evaluate Schwannomas, and it typically shows a well-defined mass arising from a nerve sheath with no invasion of surrounding tissues.

Incorrect choices:
 
Option A. Lipomas are benign tumours that arise from adipose tissue. They are typically soft, mobile, and painless masses. On histology, they show mature adipocytes arranged in lobules. Lipomas do not arise from a nerve sheath and do not show spindle-shaped cells arranged in a palisading pattern.
 
Option B. Neurofibromas are benign tumours that arise from nerve cells and their supporting cells. They are typically slow-growing, well-circumscribed, and mobile masses. They show a mixture of Schwann cells, nerve fibres, and fibroblasts on histology. Neurofibromas do not show spindle-shaped cells arranged in a palisading pattern.
 
Option C. Gastrointestinal stromal tumour is incorrect. Gastrointestinal stromal tumours (GISTs) are rare tumours that arise from Cajal's interstitial cells, which regulate gut motility. They typically present with gastrointestinal bleeding, abdominal pain, or a palpable mass. On histology, they show spindle-shaped cells arranged in a whorled pattern, but they do not show spindle-shaped cells arranged in a palisading pattern. GISTs do not arise from a nerve sheath.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents a history of fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On examination, she has a diffuse goitre with no nodules or tenderness, as seen in the image. Her thyroid function tests show elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and low free thyroxine (FT4) levels. Thyroid peroxidase antibody (TPOAb) levels are also elevated. A fine-needle aspiration thyroid biopsy shows lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cell changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that causes chronic thyroid gland inflammation, leading to hypothyroidism. It is characterized by the presence of lymphocytic infiltration and Hurthle cell changes on histology. The diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis is based on clinical presentation, thyroid function tests, and the presence of TPOAb. 

Patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis typically present with a diffuse goitre, fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance, as seen in this case. Thyroid function tests show elevated TSH and low FT4 levels, indicating hypothyroidism. TPOAb levels are also elevated, confirming the autoimmune nature of the disease.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and typically presents as a solitary nodule or a dominant nodule in a multinodular goitre. It is characterized by nuclear features such as nuclear grooves and pseudo-inclusions. Thyroid function tests are usually normal in patients with papillary thyroid carcinoma, and TPOAb levels are not typically elevated.

Option B. Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare but aggressive type of thyroid cancer that typically presents as a rapidly growing mass in the neck. A lack of differentiation and aggressive histological features characterises its features. Thyroid function tests are usually normal in patients with anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, and TPOAb levels are not typically elevated.

Option C. Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that causes hyperthyroidism. It is characterized by the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin (TSI) and diffuse goitre with or without nodules. Patients with Graves' disease typically present with weight loss, heat intolerance, and tremors, opposite to the symptoms seen in this case. Thyroid function tests in Graves' disease show low TSH and high FT4 levels, indicating hyperthyroidism. TPOAb levels are not typically elevated in Graves' disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent kidney stones and abdominal pain. He also reports a family history of pancreatic tumours and hyperparathyroidism. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Laboratory investigations show elevated serum calcium levels, parathyroid hormone, and urinary calcium excretion. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features seen in this patient, including hypercalcemia, hyperparathyroidism, and a family history of pancreatic tumours and hyperparathyroidism, are consistent with the diagnosis of MEN1.

MEN1 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of tumours in multiple endocrine organs, including the parathyroid glands, pancreas, and pituitary gland. It is caused by mutations in the MEN1 gene, which encodes for a tumour suppressor protein called menin. 

The most common tumours associated with MEN1 are parathyroid adenomas, pancreatic islet cell tumours (including insulinomas, gastrinomas, and glucagonomas), and pituitary adenomas. Patients with MEN1 may also develop adrenal tumours, lipomas, and angiofibromas. 

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a rare type of thyroid cancer associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). It is characterised by the production of calcitonin by the tumour cells and can be diagnosed by measuring serum calcitonin levels. Patients with MEN2 may also develop pheochromocytomas and parathyroid hyperplasia, not pancreatic tumours.

Option B. Pheochromocytoma is an adrenal gland tumour that produces excess catecholamines. It can cause hypertension, palpitations, and other symptoms of excess sympathetic activity. While pheochromocytomas can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), they are not typically seen in MEN1.

Option D. MEN2A is also an autosomal dominant disorder characterised by the development of tumours in the thyroid gland, adrenal gland, and parathyroid gland. The most common tumours associated with MEN2A are medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid hyperplasia. However, MEN2A is not associated with pancreatic tumours, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid produces calcitonin, a hormone that helps regulate calcium levels in the body. It can occur sporadically or as part of an inherited genetic syndrome, such as multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). 

It develops from the parafollicular C-cells and secretes calcitonin. Therefore, positive immunohistochemical staining for calcitonin is the characteristic feature of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. 

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A. Psammoma bodies are commonly seen in parathyroid papillary carcinomatous.

Option B. Positive immunohistochemical staining for thyroglobulin is seen in papillary and follicular carcinoma of the thyroid. 

Option D. The presence of papillary projections is seen in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and bad breath for the past few months. On examination, there is no cervical lymphadenopathy or thyroid enlargement. Barium swallow reveals a posterior outpouching of the pharyngeal mucosa just above the upper esophageal sphincter. A diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum is suspected. Which of the following is the most likely pathogenesis of Zenker's diverticulum in this patient?

choices.text: Infection of the pharynx causing inflammation and weakening of the pharyngeal muscles
Chronic irritation of the esophagus due to acid reflux
Congenital malformation of the pharynx and esophagus
Weakness in the muscle layer between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
Zenker's diverticulum is a condition that occurs when a pouch-like sac protrudes from the pharynx (throat) through a weak area in the wall of the esophagus near the upper esophageal sphincter. This outpouching is called a diverticulum, 
It is a diverticulum formed in the hypopharynx, usually in the muscle layer between the cricopharyngeus (CP) and thyropharyngeus muscles. However, it is a false diverticulum since it only affects the mucosa and submucosal layers, not the muscle layer.
Incorrect choices
Option A. Infection of the pharynx causing inflammation is not a known cause of Zenker's diverticulum. 
Option B. Acid reflux is associated with developing oesophageal strictures and Barrett's oesophagus but not Zenker's diverticulum. 
Option C. Congenital malformations are not known to cause Zenker's diverticulum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent abdominal pain and episodes of intestinal obstruction. She also reports having multiple small brown spots on her lips and oral mucosa. Family history is significant for similar skin lesions and gastrointestinal polyps in her father and siblings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant genetic disease affecting multiple body organ systems, particularly the gastrointestinal tract. It is characterized by developing gastrointestinal polyps and pigmented spots on the lips and oral mucosa. These pigmented spots are called melanin spots and are usually present at birth or develop during childhood.
Incorrect Choices: 
Option A. Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) is another genetic disorder that causes the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon, leading to an increased risk of colorectal cancer. However, FAP does not typically present with melanin spots. 
Option B. Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), also known as Lynch syndrome, is another genetic disorder that increases the risk of colorectal cancer. However, it does not typically present with melanin spots or multiple polyps in the gastrointestinal tract. 
Option D. Cowden syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple benign tumors in various organs, including the skin, mucous membranes, thyroid, and breast, but it does not typically present with melanin spots or gastrointestinal polyps.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with a painless swelling in the parotid region that has gradually increased in size over the last few months. He has a history of smoking cigarettes for the past 30 years. On examination, the swelling is found to be soft, non-tender, and mobile. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) reveals the presence of epithelial cells and lymphoid cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

Warthin tumor is a benign neoplasm of the salivary gland that is also known as papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum. It typically occurs in older male patients who have a history of smoking. 

It presents as a painless, slow-growing mass in the parotid gland that is composed of cystic spaces lined by oncocytic cells and lymphoid tissue. The cytology of Warthin tumor usually shows the presence of epithelial cells and lymphoid cells.

Incorrect choices: 

Option A. Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary gland. It typically presents as a painless, slowly enlarging mass that is well-defined and mobile. The cytology of pleomorphic adenoma usually shows a mixture of epithelial and myoepithelial cells.

Option C. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant salivary gland tumour that arises from the mucous and epidermoid cells. It can present as a painless mass, but it can also cause pain or facial nerve paralysis. The cytology of mucoepidermoid carcinoma shows the presence of mucous cells, epidermoid cells, and intermediate cells.

Option D. Adenoid cystic carcinoma is a malignant salivary gland tumor that typically presents as a slowly growing mass. It can invade surrounding tissues and cause nerve paralysis. The cytology of adenoid cystic carcinoma shows the presence of ductal cells, myoepithelial cells, and cribriform structures.

questions.text: Which of the following is a germ cell tumor of the testis?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Seminoma is a particular kind of germ cell tumour that develops in the testes. In males and females, germ cells develop into sperm or eggs. 
Seminomas typically develop in the testicles but can also develop in the brain, chest, or belly. It is the most common type of testicular cancer and usually affects men ages 20 to 40.  Seminomas often advance slowly. 
Incorrect Choices:
Option B. Sertoli cell tumor is a rare type of testicular tumor that arises from the Sertoli cells of the testes. These tumors can secrete estrogen and other hormones, leading to gynecomastia and other symptoms. 
Option C. Leydig cell tumor is another rare type of testicular tumor that arises from the Leydig cells of the testes. These tumors can produce testosterone and other androgens, leading to virilization and other symptoms. 
Option D. Granulosa cell tumor is a type of ovarian tumour that arises from the granulosa cells of the ovary. These tumors can produce estrogen and other hormones, leading to symptoms such as abnormal uterine bleeding and breast tenderness.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease (VWD)?

choices.text: VWD is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of factor VIII.
VWD is an X-linked recessive disorder.
VWD results in impaired platelet function and defective clotting factor activation.
VWD is characterized by decreased levels of fibrinogen.

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Von Willebrand disease (VWD) is a genetic bleeding disorder that affects the ability of blood to clot properly. It is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor (VWF), a glycoprotein that plays a key role in activating platelet adhesion and clotting factor.
Incorrect choices: 
Option A. Factor VIII deficiency is the cause of haemophilia A, not VWD. 
Option B. VWD can be inherited in an autosomal dominant or recessive pattern, not just X-linked. 
Option D. Fibrinogen levels are not typically affected in VWD.

questions.text: Which of the following enzyme is not involved in the glycolytic pathway?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.
Pyruvate dehydrogenase catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate (end product of glycolysis) into acetyl-CoA, which enters the citric acid cycle for further energy production. Thus, pyruvate dehydrogenase is not a part of the glycolytic pathway.
Incorrect Choices:
Option A. Hexokinase is the enzyme responsible for the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate, which is the first step in the glycolytic pathway. 
Option B. Aldolase catalyzes the cleavage of fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate into two triose phosphates, which continue down the glycolytic pathway. 
Option D. Enolase converts 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate in the glycolytic pathway.

questions.text: Which one of the following enzymes is involved in lipogenesis?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Lipogenesis is a metabolic process comprising fatty acid synthesis and subsequent triglyceride synthesis. In this process, fatty acids and glycerol are converted into fats for storage. This process takes place in both the liver and adipose tissues.

Acetyl-CoA carboxylase (ACC) catalyses the conversion (irreversible carboxylation) of acetyl-CoA to malonyl-CoA, the first step in the fatty acid synthesis. It is present in the cytoplasm of most eukaryotes.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B: The enzyme lipase catalyses fat molecule breaks down or hydrolysis. It is a digestive enzyme synthesised in the pancreas, salivary glands and stomach.

Option C: Protease enzymes catalyse the breakdown or hydrolysis of peptide bonds, with most enzymes cleaving the alpha-peptide bond. This releases single amino acids or smaller polypeptides that can further form different protein products. These enzymes are also involved in cell signalling.

Option D: Amylase is another digestive enzyme synthesised by the pancreas and the salivary glands. This enzyme catalyses the breaks down or hydrolysis of carbohydrates. In humans, amylase is present in the saliva and initiates the process of chemical digestion of food in humans.

questions.text: What is the respiratory quotient (RQ)?

choices.text: The ratio of glucose consumption to oxygen consumption.
The ratio of oxygen consumption to glucose consumption.
The ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen consumption by using expelled air.
The ratio of carbon dioxide production to oxygen consumption at cellular levels.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

The ratio of carbon dioxide generation to oxygen consumption is the respiratory quotient (RQ) during aerobic respiration. This ratio reflects the type of fuel being oxidized by the body for energy production.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. The glucose consumption to oxygen consumption ratio is different from the respiratory quotient.
Option B. The ratio of oxygen consumption to glucose consumption is not the same as the RQ.
Option C. The respiratory exchange ratio (RER) measures how much oxygen is used and how much carbon dioxide is produced while breathing out air. Unlike RQ, RER is measured at the mouth or nose.

questions.text: Substrate level phosphorylation occurs during which of the following metabolic pathways?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
Substrate-level phosphorylation is a metabolic pathway that generates ATP by directly transferring a phosphate group from a high-energy substrate molecule. This process occurs in both glycolysis and the Krebs cycle, the two main metabolic pathways responsible for generating ATP through cellular respiration.
Incorrect choices:
Option A. Substrate-level phosphorylation occurs during glycolysis. Glycolysis is a metabolic pathway that occurs in the cytosol of cells, and it is the first step in glucose metabolism. During glycolysis, glucose is converted to pyruvate via a series of enzymatic reactions, some of which generate ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation. Specifically, the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3-bisphosphoglycerate generates ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation.
Option B. Substrate-level phosphorylation also occurs during the Krebs, known as the citric acid cycle or tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. The Krebs cycle is a metabolic pathway that occurs in the mitochondria of cells and is responsible for generating energy in the form of ATP. During the Krebs cycle, acetyl-CoA is oxidized to CO2, and electrons are transferred to NAD+ and FAD to produce NADH and FADH2, respectively. Some of the reactions in the Krebs cycle generate ATP through substrate-level phosphorylation, specifically the conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate, which generates GTP, which can then be converted to ATP. 


Option D. The electron transport chain is a series of proteins and enzymes located in the inner mitochondrial membrane. During this process, electrons are transported down a chain of redox enzymes, producing a large amount of ATP molecules. However, the production of ATP in the electron transport chain occurs through oxidative phosphorylation, which is a completely different mechanism than substrate-level phosphorylation

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with developmental delay, hepatosplenomegaly, and recurrent infections. His parents report that he also has episodes of diarrhoea and vomiting. Physical examination shows coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, and a large tongue. Laboratory investigations reveal low platelet count and elevated liver enzymes. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Lysosomal storage diseases refer to the class of inborn metabolic error diseases characterized by the accumulation of excessive organ substrates due to a lack of lysosome enzymes. These are rare genetic disorders with symptoms ranging from developmental delay and hepatosplenomegaly to recurrent infections.
  • Gaucher disease is a lysosomal storage disease involving the build-up of certain fatty substances in the spleen and liver. This accumulation of fatty substances causes the organs to enlarge, adversely affecting their function. The symptoms of Gaucher disease include coarse facial features, a prominent forehead, enlarged spleen and liver, yellow spots in eyes, bruising, fatigue, a large tongue, etc. Further, tests showing a low platelet count and elevated liver enzymes indicate a diagnosis of Gaucher disease.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Niemann-Pick disease is another lysosomal storage disease caused by a deficiency in the enzymes sphingomyelinase or acid sphingomyelinase. A person having Niemann-Pick disease exhibits neurological symptoms, hepatosplenomegaly, and foam cells in the bone marrow. 

Option, C. Tay-Sachs disease is caused by the deficiency of hexosaminidase A enzyme. This leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in neurons, causing progressive neurological degeneration. The common symptoms of this disease are muscular weakness, difficulty in speaking and swallowing, seizures, and hearing and vision loss.

Option D. Pompe disease is caused by the deficiency of the enzyme acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes of various organs, including the heart, skeletal muscles, and liver causing weakness, cardiomyopathy, and respiratory failure. The symptoms of this disease include muscle weakness, feeding problem, enlarged heart, trouble in breathing and poor weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following coenzymes is involved in the transfer of acyl groups?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Coenzyme A (CoA), a ubiquitous co-enzyme, transfers acyl groups, which is important for metabolizing fatty acids, cholesterol, and carbohydrates. It facilitates the oxidation of pyruvate in the TCA cycle. 

CoA binds to the acyl group and forms a high-energy thioester bond, which allows the acyl group to transfer to another molecule. The SH group present on co-enzyme A forms thioesters and activates acyl groups for transfer by the nucleophilic reaction. The SH group also activates the alpha-hydrogen on the acyl group for abstraction as a proton.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. NADH (nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide) is a coenzyme composed of two nucleotides, one containing an adenine base and the other a nicotinamide base, with the two nucleotides joined through their phosphate groups. This coenzyme accepts electrons during the oxidation of substrates and donates them to the electron transport chain.

Option C. FADH2 or the hydroquinone form of FAD, is the reduced form of flavin adenine dinucleotide. It donates its electrons directly to the electron transport chain. 

Option D. Coenzyme Q or ubiquinone, is another ubiquitous coenzyme involved in electron transport. It shuttles electrons between complex I and II of the electron transport chain.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a key enzyme in ketogenesis?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

Ketogenesis is a catabolic process involving the oxidation of fatty and ketogenic amino acids to produce ketone bodies. Acetyl CoA carboxylase catalyses the carboxylation of acetyl CoA to malonyl CoA, a precursor for synthesizing fatty acids. The enzyme regulates fatty acid metabolism by producing malonyl CoA and inhibiting the beta-oxidation of fatty acids in the mitochondria.

Incorrect Choices: 

Option A. Acetyl CoA acetyltransferase catalyzes the condensation of two molecules of acetyl-CoA to form acetoacetyl-CoA in the cholesterol synthesis pathway. This enzyme belongs to the acetyltransferase enzyme family that transfers groups other than aminoacyl groups.

Option B. HMG CoA synthase catalyses the addition of a third acetyl-CoA molecule to acetoacetyl-CoA to form HMG-CoA in the mevalonate pathway. This enzyme belongs to the acetyltransferase enzyme family that cconvertsacyl groups into alkyl groups after transfer.

Option C. Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in gluconeogenesis and catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, later forming glucose. This enzyme belongs to the class ligase.

questions.text: Which of the following transporters is responsible for the transport of glucose across the plasma membrane of most mammalian cells?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Among the different isoforms of GLUT transporters, GLUT1 is the most widely distributed. It is responsible for basal glucose uptake in most tissues, including the brain, red blood cells, and endothelial cells. 
Incorrect Choices: 
Option B. GLUT2 is primarily expressed in the liver, pancreas, and small intestine, which mediates glucose uptake and release in response to changes in blood glucose levels. 
Option C. GLUT3 is expressed in neurons and other tissues with high energy demands, which mediates glucose uptake for energy metabolism. 
Option D. GLUT4 is primarily expressed in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, where it is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake.

questions.text: The Warburg effect is a phenomenon observed in cancer cells in which they exhibit the following:

choices.text: Increased glucose uptake and lactate production
Decreased glucose uptake and lactate production

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
The Warburg effect is a metabolic phenomenon observed in cancer cells, in which they exhibit increased glucose uptake and lactate production, even in the presence of oxygen. 
Incorrect Choices: 
Option A. Increased oxidative phosphorylation is not consistent with the Warburg effect. 
Option C. Decreased glucose uptake and lactate production is also inconsistent with the Warburg effect, as cancer cells exhibit increased glucose uptake and lactate production. 
Option D. Decreased oxidative phosphorylation is partially correct. The Warburg effect is associated with decreased oxidative phosphorylation in cancer cells, but this alone cannot explain the phenomenon.

questions.text: The structure given below is of:
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. 
Essential amino acids are not synthesized in living organisms' bodies and are procured through diet, whereas non-essential amino acids are synthesized in living organisms' bodies. Aspartate is a non-essential amino acid and is also involved in the biosynthesis of proteins. 
Aspartate contains 4 carbon atoms, of which 2 are carbonyl carbon atoms of carboxyl groups. The structure of aspartate is given below-


Incorrect Choices: 
Option A. Lysine is an essential amino acid that can be obtained from foods rich in protein sources such as meat, poultry, Spirulina, soybeans, etc. In the human body, lysine is necessary to produce collagen protein. The structure of lysine is given below-


Option C. Histidine is another essential amino acid that can also be procured from protein-rich foods such as animal meat, fish, kidney beans, etc. Histidine performs several functions in the human body, such as protecting of nerve cells, repairing damaged tissues, creating histamine, etc. the structure of histidine is given below-


Option D. Glutamate is a non-essential amino acid that helps the brain transmit signals to and from other cells in vertebrates. It is also used in the biosynthesis of proteins. The structure of glutamate is given below.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chronic anemia receives a transfusion of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) for an acute exacerbation of her anemia. Shortly after the transfusion begins, she develops a fever, chills, and shortness of breath. The transfusion is stopped, and the patient is evaluated for a transfusion reaction. Which of the following is the most likely transfusion reaction that the patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
 
An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction is a severe transfusion reaction that occurs due to the destruction of donor red blood cells by recipient antibodies. The symptoms of this reaction include fever, chills, hypotension, tachycardia, flank pain, and hemoglobinuria. 
 
This reaction is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening if not recognized and treated promptly. It is the most likely transfusion reaction that the patient is experiencing in the given scenario, as she experiences fever, chills, and shortness of breath, which suggest a severe reaction.
 
Incorrect Choices: 
 
Option A. Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction is a common transfusion reaction that occurs due to a reaction between donor leukocytes and recipient antibodies. The symptoms of this reaction include fever, chills, and sometimes mild dyspnea. It is usually a self-limited reaction and can be treated with antipyretics. However, this reaction is unlikely in the given scenario as the patient also experiences shortness of breath, which suggests a more severe reaction.
 
Option C. Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction is a transfusion reaction that occurs several days after a transfusion and is caused by recipient antibodies that were not present at the time of the transfusion. The symptoms of this reaction include a gradual decline in hemoglobin levels and the presence of antibodies against the transfused red blood cells. This reaction is unlikely in the given scenario as the patient experiences symptoms shortly after the transfusion begins.
 
Option D., Allergic transfusion reaction, is a rare transfusion reaction due to an allergic reaction to donor plasma proteins. The symptoms of this reaction include urticaria, itching, and flushing. This reaction is unlikely in the given scenario as the patient experiences fever, chills, and shortness of breath, which suggest a more severe reaction.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with type 1 diabetes presents with abdominal pain and vomiting. On laboratory testing, she has a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms. DKA is a potentially life-threatening complication of type 1 diabetes that results from a relative insulin deficiency and an increase in counter-regulatory hormones, such as glucagon and catecholamines. 

This leads to increased hepatic gluconeogenesis and ketogenesis, resulting in the accumulation of ketone bodies (acetoacetate, beta-hydroxybutyrate, and acetone) in the blood, which leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Abdominal pain and vomiting are often the presenting symptoms of DKA, and laboratory testing typically shows hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and an elevated anion gap.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Lactic acidosis is caused by the accumulation of lactate in the blood, resulting from various conditions, including hypoperfusion, hypoxia, sepsis, and certain medications. However, it is less likely because of the patient’s symptoms, as lactic acidosis typically results in a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, rather than a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option C. Hyperchloremic acidosis occurs when there is an excess of chloride ions in the blood, resulting in a decrease in bicarbonate levels and a compensatory increase in the chloride-bicarbonate exchange. This can result from conditions such as diarrhea, renal tubular acidosis, or excessive administration of chloride-containing solutions. However, it is less likely to cause the patient's symptoms in this case, as hyperchloremic acidosis typically results in a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, rather than a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Option D. Respiratory acidosis occurs when there is an excess of carbon dioxide in the blood due to hypoventilation, resulting in increased carbonic acid and decreased pH. However, it is less likely to cause the patient's symptoms in this case, as respiratory acidosis typically results in a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis rather than a high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Additionally, the patient’s abdominal pain and vomiting symptoms are not typical of respiratory acidosis, usually associated with respiratory distress and shortness of breath.

questions.text: In the colon, bacterial fermentation of fibres produces short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs). Which of the following is not a function of SCFAs?

choices.text: Provide a major source of energy for colonocytes
Stimulate the release of satiety hormones
Regulate immune function in the gut

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs) are a group of fatty acids produced by the fermentation of dietary fiber by gut bacteria in the large intestine. They play an important role in maintaining gut health and overall health. There are three main SCFAs: acetate, propionate, and butyrate.
  • SCFAs do not stimulate gluconeogenesis in the liver. Gluconeogenesis is the liver's process of producing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources such as amino and fatty acids. While SCFAs can be converted to glucose in the liver, they do not stimulate this process. SCFAs are typically used as a source of energy by the liver rather than being converted to glucose.

Incorrect Choices:
 
Option A. SCFAs are an important source of energy for colonocytes, the cells that line the colon. These cells require a constant supply of energy to function properly. SCFAs are absorbed by the colonocytes and used as a fuel source for various metabolic processes. Without SCFAs, colonocytes can become damaged, leading to inflammation and other gut disorders.
 
Option B. SCFAs have been shown to stimulate the release of satiety hormones such as peptide YY (PYY) and glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1). These hormones signal the brain to reduce appetite and increase feelings of fullness, which can lead to decreased food intake and potentially aid in weight management.
 
Option C. SCFAs have been shown to regulate gut immune function by promoting beneficial gut bacteria growth and reducing inflammation. They also help to maintain the integrity of the gut barrier, which prevents harmful bacteria and toxins from entering the bloodstream and causing systemic inflammation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. She reports a history of gallstones and a recent high-fat meal. Laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of pancreatic enzymes. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired fat digestion due to gallstone obstruction of the common bile duct.
Increased fat absorption due to a deficiency of pancreatic lipase.
Enhanced fat absorption due to a deficiency of bile salts.
Decreased fat absorption due to a deficiency of chylomicrons.

questions.solution:
Option A is correct. 

Impaired fat digestion due to gallstone obstruction of the common bile duct is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms. Bile salts are necessary for the emulsification of fat, and obstruction of the common bile duct can prevent the release of bile into the small intestine, leading to impaired fat digestion and subsequent abdominal symptoms.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. A pancreatic lipase deficiency would lead to impaired digestion rather than increased fat absorption. Pancreatic lipase is required to break down triglycerides into fatty acids and glycerol for absorption.
