Option C: Acoustic neuroma is a rare, benign nerve tumour that controls hearing and balance and usually presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and vestibular symptoms such as vertigo. However, the soft-tissue mass seen on imaging, in this case, is unlikely to be an acoustic neuroma, as it is not located in the area of the vestibulocochlear nerve.

Option D: Meniere's disease is a condition characterized by recurrent episodes of vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss, but it typically presents with symptoms in both ears rather than just one.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with a 3-month history of progressive dysphonia and occasional dysphagia. Laryngoscopy reveals a smooth, nodular lesion on the right vocal cord, and the biopsy confirms a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The patient is staged as T1N0M0. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

The standard treatment for T1N0M0 laryngeal cancer is surgical resection. Surgery offers a high chance of cure for early-stage laryngeal cancer with a low risk of functional impairment. The goal of surgery is to remove the tumour while preserving vocal function. Various surgical techniques can be used depending on the size and location of the tumour, including transoral laser microsurgery, open partial laryngectomy, or endoscopic resection.

Incorrect Choices:    

Option A: Radiation therapy may be considered an alternative to surgery for T1N0M0 laryngeal cancer, but it is associated with a higher risk of long-term functional impairment and can be less effective at achieving local control.

Option B: Chemotherapy alone is not considered a standard treatment for T1N0M0 laryngeal cancer. It may be combined with radiation therapy for more advanced diseases or as a palliative treatment for metastatic disease.

Option D: Watchful waiting is inappropriate for early-stage laryngeal cancer, as it is a potentially curable malignancy requiring active treatment.

questions.text: A 36-year-old patient complains of persistent headache, nasal obstruction, and ear fullness. On examination, there is tenderness over the nasopharyngeal area, and endoscopy reveals a bulging mass in the roof of the nasopharynx. CT scan shows a fluid-filled sac in the region. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate treatment?

choices.text: Nasopharyngeal bursitis, antibiotics and nasal decongestants

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • The clinical presentation, along with the endoscopic and radiological findings, are suggestive of nasopharyngeal bursitis. It is an uncommon condition characterized by inflammation and swelling of the bursa in the nasopharynx's roof. The bursa is a small sac lined with synovial membrane and filled with fluid, which helps in reducing friction between adjacent structures. 
  • Inflammation of this bursa can occur due to infection, trauma, or autoimmune disorders. The symptoms include persistent headache, nasal obstruction, ear fullness, and tenderness over the nasopharyngeal area. Endoscopy may reveal a bulging mass in the region, and a CT scan can confirm the diagnosis by showing a fluid-filled sac in the area. The treatment of nasopharyngeal bursitis involves antibiotics to treat the infection, nasal decongestants to reduce the swelling, and pain relievers to alleviate the headache.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumour originating in the nasopharynx. It is associated with the Epstein-Barr virus and is more common in certain populations, such as those of Chinese or Southeast Asian descent. The symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma may include persistent nasal obstruction, bloody nasal discharge, hearing loss, and cranial nerve palsies. Treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

Option C: Juvenile angiofibroma is a benign vascular tumour that arises from the nasopharynx. It is more common in adolescent males and may present with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and facial swelling. Treatment involves surgical excision, which can be challenging due to the tumour's location and vascularity.

Option D: Nasopharyngeal polyps are benign growths arising from the nasopharynx's mucosa. They may present with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, and snoring. Treatment typically involves endoscopic resection, a minimally invasive procedure that removes the polyp while preserving surrounding tissue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of recurrent throat pain, dysphagia, and otalgia. CT imaging reveals elongation and calcification of the styloid process bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the styloid process

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

The patient's clinical presentation and imaging findings are consistent with Eagle syndrome, a condition characterized by elongation of the styloid process or calcification of the stylohyoid ligament. The most effective treatment for Eagle syndrome is surgical resection of the elongated or calcified styloid process. The procedure can be performed transorally or transcervically, depending on the location and extent of the calcification.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Conservative management with analgesics may temporarily relieve symptoms, but it is not an effective long-term solution for Eagle syndrome.

Option C: Botulinum toxin injection is a relatively new treatment option for Eagle syndrome. However, the evidence supporting its efficacy is limited, and it is not considered a standard treatment.

Option D: Radiotherapy is not an appropriate treatment for Eagle syndrome, as it is not a malignant condition and does not require radiation therapy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a severe sore throat, fever, and malaise. Examination reveals ulcers with a greyish-white pseudomembrane on the tonsils and posterior pharynx. The patient is diagnosed with Vincent's angina. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Vincent's angina, also known as trench mouth, is an acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis caused by a synergistic infection of spirochetes (such as Treponema) and fusiform bacteria (such as Fusobacterium). Treatment consists of antimicrobial therapy, usually with oral metronidazole or penicillin. 
  • Metronidazole is preferred due to its better anaerobic coverage and ability to penetrate oral tissues. Intravenous penicillin can be used if the patient cannot tolerate oral medications or has severe systemic symptoms. Symptomatic relief can be achieved with local anaesthetics, analgesics, and warm saline rinses.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Intravenous penicillin is a treatment option for Vincent's angina; however, oral metronidazole is preferred due to its better anaerobic coverage and ability to penetrate oral tissues.

Option C: Topical corticosteroids are not used to treat Vincent's angina, as they have no antimicrobial effect and may even exacerbate the condition.

Option D: Nasal decongestants do not treat Vincent's angina, as the condition primarily affects the oral cavity and oropharynx, not the nasal passages.

questions.text: A 65-year-old Peter presented with complaints of progressive dysphagia, odynophagia, ear pain, and weight loss. A laryngoscopy showed a suspicious growth in the pyriform fossa- suggestive of carcinoma. The likely condition was explained. Peter, however, wants to know why a growth in his throat would cause him pain in the ear. What nerve may be anatomically responsible for this pain?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • In pyriform sinus cancer, pain is sent to the ear via the internal laryngeal nerve. The internal laryngeal nerve is one of the two branches of the superior laryngeal nerve. The internal laryngeal nerve supplies sensory innervation to the laryngeal mucosa down to the voice cords (supraglottic larynx) level. 
  • Dysphagia, odynophagia, and the perception of a foreign body can all be brought on by an enlarged triticeal cartilage compressing the internal laryngeal nerve.

Incorrect options:


Option A: The external laryngeal nerve supplies the cricothyroid muscle; it descends on the larynx just behind the sternothyroid muscle. The external branch causes the cricothyroid muscle to contract, tensing the vocal cords and raising the pitch.

Option B: All the intrinsic laryngeal muscles, with the exception of the cricothyroid muscles, are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), a branch of the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X).
 

Option D: The hypoglossal nerve innervates all the extrinsic and intrinsic muscles of the tongue except for the palatoglossus, which is innervated by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with a history of complaints of fishbone stuck in his throat. He, however, did not seek medical help then. He now presented with dysphagia, pain, fever, and difficulty moving his neck. On examination, the patient looks ill, and stridor is present. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

  • Retropharyngeal abscess is more commonly seen in extremes of age, where the patient may be very young or old. Considering the detail of a foreign body stuck in the throat (penetrating injury) that gradually turned into an abscess, a retropharyngeal abscess is a possible explanation. The development of this condition results from serious microbial infection in the location of the injury.
  • Clinical features of retropharyngeal abscess are dysphagia, difficulty in breathing, difficulty swallowing, stridor, high fever, difficulty turning the head, and croupy cough. Torticollis may be present along with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall. All these signs are presented in the patient, and hence, the possible diagnosis for the given condition is a retropharyngeal abscess.

Incorrect choices:

Option B: In parapharyngeal abscess, clinical features depend on the compartment involved. Prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa, trismus (caused by a spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle), and external swelling behind the angle of the jaw are the three signs of anterior compartment infections. The protrusion of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, the paralysis of the sympathetic chain and CN IX, X, XI, and XII, and the swelling of the parotid area are all symptoms of posterior compartment involvement. They are also associated with fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (caused by a prevertebral muscular spasm), and odynophagia.

Option C: Peritonsillar abscess is common in adults and rarely in children. Clinical features are fever, headache, nausea, odynophagia, muffled hot potato voice, earache, foul breath, and trismus.

Option D: Usually due to dental infections. Features are odynophagia, the floor of the mouth is swollen, and submental and submandibular areas are hard and tender. Laryngeal edema may be present.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents to the ophthalmology clinic complaining of severe headache and blurred vision. The patient's best-corrected visual acuity is 20/20 in both eyes. On further examination, the ophthalmologist notices a dilated and tortuous vein running over the optic disc in the patient's left eye. A fluorescein angiogram reveals an area of hyper fluorescence around the optic disc. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what other structures in the eye should be examined to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO); anterior chamber
Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO); vitreous humour
Non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION); macula

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The patient's symptoms, including headache and blurred vision, and the ophthalmologist's findings, including a dilated and tortuous vein running over the optic disc in the left eye and an area of hyper fluorescence around the optic disc on fluorescein angiography, suggest the diagnosis of NAION. NAION is a condition in which the blood flow to the optic nerve is compromised, leading to ischemia and subsequent optic nerve damage.
  • Other structures in the eye that should be examined to confirm the diagnosis of NAION include the macula, as the condition can cause damage to this area of the retina. In addition, the ophthalmologist should thoroughly examine the optic nerve head, as this is the site of the ischemic insult in NAION.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) is incorrect because CRVO typically presents with decreased visual acuity, not just headaches and blurred vision. In addition, the anterior chamber is not a structure that needs to be examined to confirm the diagnosis of CRVO.

Option B: Branch retinal vein occlusion (BRVO) is incorrect because BRVO typically presents with sectoral visual field defects, not just headaches and blurred vision. In addition, the vitreous humour is not a structure that needs to be examined to confirm the diagnosis of BRVO.

Option D: Ischemic optic neuropathy (ION), is incorrect because ION typically presents with sudden, painless vision loss, not just headaches and blurred vision. In addition, the choroid is not a structure that needs to be examined to confirm the diagnosis of ION.

questions.text: In the 50 years old female, a change in the refractive index of the lens is found while examining.  In the physiology of eye refraction, different indices are present in various eye regions. What is the normal average refractive index of the lens?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The refractive index of lens is 1.39

 
Incorrect Choices:

Option A: 1.0 is the refractive index of air through which rays of light pass. Refractive index (n) = velocity of light in space (c)/ velocity of light in given substance (v). n=c/v for air is 1. 
 
Option B: 1.34 is the average refractive index of aqueous humour. The light rays change the medium in the interface between the cornea & aqueous humour.
 
Option D: 1.37 is of the cornea. Change in a medium in the interface between air & cornea. This gives maximum refractive power, which is 39 dioptres.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy came with a progressive diminished distant vision. He has to change the glasses every year. His glasses are becoming thicker every year. There is a recent blurring of vision. Which of the following factors is not correctly related to the condition discussed?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • The patient is suffering from progressive diminishing of distant vision with thick glasses. There is a blurring of vision. These lead to the diagnosis of high/pathological myopia. The exception in the given option is a shortening of axial length which is related to hypermetropia, not myopia. 
  • In myopia, there is an elongation of the eye that leads to an increase in the axial length. Biomechanical forces causing axial elongation to lead to progressive stretching & thinning of ocular layers.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Cataract formation is a condition that results in the clouding of the eye's natural lens, leading to blurred or dim vision. While cataracts can develop at any age, they are more commonly found in older adults. While high myopia can increase the risk of cataracts, it is not directly related to the condition discussed in the question. Therefore, option A is an incorrect choice.

Option B: Optic neuritis is a condition that results from inflammation of the optic nerve, which can lead to decreased visual acuity, eye pain, and difficulty with color vision. While optic neuritis can occur in children, it is not commonly associated with high myopia. Therefore, option F is an incorrect choice.

Option C: Macular degeneration is a condition that results in the progressive loss of central vision, often affecting individuals over the age of 50. While high myopia can increase the risk of developing macular degeneration, it is not a condition that typically presents in children. Therefore, option C is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: A 3 years old male child recently going to school complains of headache & difficulty in seeing the writing on a blackboard as he sits on the last bench. He is advised to do a retinoscopy. What is retinoscopy?

choices.text: Subjective method of finding the refractive error
An objective method of finding refractive error
Subjective method of correcting refractive error
An objective method of correcting refractive error

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • In the given case, the boy may have myopia as he has headaches and diminished vision. He has been advised retinoscopy, the objective method of finding the refractive error. It is done in this case as the boy is too young to undergo subjective refraction as it requires judgment and response. 
  • In this method, a retinoscope shines light in the patient’s eye. The reflex of the light from the retina is observed relatively with the movement of the retinoscope light. It is done when a patient is in a relaxed accommodative state. The patient is asked to see a distant object or topical cycloplegic drugs used (when the child cannot fix the gaze leading to fluctuating accommodation). 

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: The subjective method of finding a refractive error involves using different trial lenses for the best visual acuity. The trial frame is placed in front of the eyes. Lenses are put one after the other in front of the test eye with an occluder on the other. Snellen chart is used to see the visual acuity. The patient is asked to see and give a response to get the best acuity. The same is done with the other eye.

Option C: The refractive error cannot be corrected with the help of only a retinoscope. It requires the manual placing of trial lenses by an ophthalmologist to neutralize the reflex.

Option D: Retinoscope is not useful for the subjective method as it requires response and judgment of the patient while seeing through the trial lens at the Snellen chart.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female patient from a rural area presents with complaints of itching, irritation, and redness in her eyes for the past few weeks. On examination, multiple follicles are seen on the upper tarsal conjunctiva of both eyes. 



The patient reports frequent exposure to dust and flies. The ophthalmologist suspects trachoma and starts treatment accordingly. However, the patient shows deterioration after a week of the visit. On further investigation, the ophthalmologist comes to know that the patient has been using a traditional eye medication obtained from a local healer and has not used an adequate dose of antibiotics. What is the most likely cause of the lack of response and deterioration in this patient?

choices.text: Lack of compliance with the prescribed treatment

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Trachoma is a bacterial infection caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, and it is a major cause of blindness worldwide. The infection is transmitted through direct or indirect contact with eye discharge from infected individuals, and it is more common in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene. The symptoms include itching, irritation, and redness in the eyes, and the disease can progress to scarring of the cornea and blindness if left untreated.
  • The treatment of trachoma involves the use of antibiotics, such as azithromycin or tetracycline, and a combination of hygiene measures, including face washing and environmental improvement. In this case, the patient had been prescribed antibiotics for a week, but she did not show any improvement. On re-examination, it was found that the patient had been using a traditional eye medication obtained from a local healer.
  • Traditional eye medications are often used in rural areas, and they may contain harmful substances that can cause further damage to the eyes. In addition, the use of traditional eye medications may delay the diagnosis and treatment of trachoma, leading to further complications.
  • Therefore, option C, the use of traditional eye medication, is the most likely cause of the lack of response to treatment in this patient. The ophthalmologist should educate the patient about the potential harm of using traditional eye medications and encourage her to comply with the prescribed treatment. The use of antibiotics should also be continued as per the recommended dose and duration to prevent the development of drug resistance.


Incorrect choices:

Option A: Inadequate dose of antibiotics is incorrect because even if the patient diagnosed with trachoma used a less appropriate dose of antibiotics compared to the dose that has been prescribed, a complete lack of improvement is not possible, and deterioration of the condition should not have occurred.

Option B: Drug resistance is unlikely because the patient has not responded to treatment, indicating that the prescribed antibiotic is not effective. The emergence of drug resistance usually occurs with repeated and prolonged use of antibiotics.

Option D: Lack of compliance with the prescribed treatment is also a possibility, but in this case, the use of traditional eye medication is the most likely cause of the lack of response.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension presents with complaints of decreased vision in the right eye for the past 3 months. On examination, visual acuity in the right eye is 6/60, and in the left eye, it is 6/6. There is a right relative afferent pupillary defect. Fundus examination reveals optic disc pallor in the right eye with a cup-to-disc ratio of 0.8:1. MRI of the brain with contrast shows a lesion in the left parietal lobe. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient's visual pathway abnormality?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • The patient in the above case has a unilateral decrease in visual acuity, right relative afferent pupillary defect, and optic disc pallor in the right eye. These findings suggest an optic nerve abnormality. The presence of a lesion in the left parietal lobe indicates a retro chiasmal lesion.

Therefore, option D) Retrochiasmal Lesion, is the correct answer.

  • Retrochiasmal lesions affect the optic tract, lateral geniculate body, optic radiations, or the visual cortex. They can cause homonymous visual field defects and may be accompanied by other neurological deficits, depending on the location and extent of the lesion.

Incorrect Choice: 
Option A: Optic neuritis is an inflammation of the optic nerve and typically presents with painful vision loss, color desaturation, and central scotoma. It can be unilateral or bilateral and is associated with multiple sclerosis.

Option B) Optic nerve compression can occur due to various causes such as a tumor, aneurysm, or inflammation. It presents with gradual or sudden visual loss and may be accompanied by other neurological deficits.

Option C) Optic nerve trauma usually occurs due to blunt or penetrating injury and presents with acute visual loss, swelling, and disc edema.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male presents with bilateral redness, irritation, and discharge from his eyes for the past 5 days. 

On examination, the conjunctiva is congested, and there is a watery discharge. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Bilateral redness, irritation, and watery discharge from the eyes are typical symptoms of conjunctivitis, but the presence of watery discharge and conjunctival congestion suggests a viral etiology. The additional presence of preauricular lymphadenopathy and upper respiratory tract infection symptoms may further support the diagnosis of viral conjunctivitis.

  • The appropriate management for viral conjunctivitis is supportive care, including warm compresses, cool compresses, and artificial tears for symptom relief. It is important to note that antibiotics are not effective against viral infections, and topical steroids may even worsen the condition. Therefore, the most appropriate option is C) Viral conjunctivitis, supportive treatment.

Incorrect Choices:

A)    Allergic conjunctivitis, topical steroids - This option is incorrect because although it is possible to present with bilateral redness, irritation, and discharge with allergic conjunctivitis, the absence of itching and burning sensations makes it less likely. Also, topical steroids are contraindicated in the presence of infection, as they can lead to the worsening of the condition.


B)    Bacterial conjunctivitis, topical antibiotics - Bacterial conjunctivitis can also present with similar symptoms as in this case, but the absence of mucopurulent discharge and conjunctival discharge makes it less likely. However, if it was bacterial conjunctivitis, topical antibiotics would be the appropriate management.

 

C)    Chemical conjunctivitis, irrigation of eyes - Chemical conjunctivitis can present with similar symptoms as in this case, but it would be more likely if there was a history of chemical exposure. Therefore, this option is less likely in the absence of a history of chemical exposure. However, if it was chemical conjunctivitis, then irrigation of the eyes would be the appropriate management.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant presents to the pediatric ophthalmology clinic complaining of tearing, photophobia, and a cloudy cornea in the right eye. On examination, the ophthalmologist notes an enlarged cornea with increased intraocular pressure (IOP) in the right eye. Gonioscopy reveals an absence of the trabecular meshwork. The left eye appears normal. Which is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the appropriate treatment for this condition?

choices.text: Primary angle-closure glaucoma; laser peripheral iridotomy

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • The patient's symptoms of tearing, photophobia, and cloudy cornea, along with an enlarged cornea and increased IOP in the right eye, suggest a diagnosis of congenital glaucoma. A Gonioscopy revealing an absence of the trabecular meshwork confirms the diagnosis. Congenital glaucoma is a rare condition that typically presents in infancy or early childhood and is characterized by an obstruction of the trabecular meshwork, leading to increased IOP and optic nerve damage.
  • The appropriate treatment for congenital glaucoma is surgical intervention. Options include goniotomy, trabeculotomy, and trabeculectomy. Surgery aims to create a new outflow pathway for aqueous humour and lower IOP to prevent optic nerve damage and preserve vision.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Primary open-angle glaucoma typically presents in adults and is not associated with an enlarged cornea or congenital abnormalities. The appropriate treatment for primary open-angle glaucoma is topical medications such as beta-blockers, prostaglandin analogues, or alpha-agonists.

Option B: Primary angle-closure glaucoma typically presents in older adults and is not associated with congenital abnormalities. The appropriate treatment for primary angle-closure glaucoma is laser peripheral iridotomy to create a new outflow pathway for aqueous humour.

Option C: Secondary glaucoma is caused by other ocular or systemic conditions, such as uveitis or diabetes, and is not associated with congenital abnormalities. The appropriate treatment for secondary glaucoma depends on the underlying cause.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of joint pain and swelling in his left ankle and left knee. He reports that the pain is severe and is associated with stiffness and difficulty in walking. On physical examination, the affected joints are erythematous, warm to touch, and tender on palpation. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum uric acid levels. X-ray of the affected joints shows erosions and sclerosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Perform a synovial fluid aspiration and analysis

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • The patient's symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with the diagnosis of gout, a type of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and soft tissues. The occurrence of recurrent episodes of joint pain and swelling in the patient suggests that the most appropriate management would involve the lowering of serum uric acid levels. It can be achieved with medications such as allopurinol, febuxostat, or probenecid.
  • In addition to pharmacologic therapy, patients with gout should be advised to make lifestyle modifications such as avoiding high-purine foods and alcohol, losing weight if overweight or obese, and exercising regularly. Patients with recurrent or severe attacks of gout may benefit from referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management.

Incorrect Choice: 

Option A: Initiate treatment with colchicine: Colchicine is a medication used to treat acute gout attacks. It works by reducing inflammation and preventing the formation of new urate crystals. It is not used for long-term management of gout, as it can have significant side effects such as gastrointestinal upset and bone marrow suppression.

Option B: Prescribe oral corticosteroids: Oral corticosteroids such as prednisone may be used to treat acute attacks of gout in patients who cannot tolerate or do not respond to colchicine or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). However, corticosteroids are generally not used for the long-term management of gout due to the risk of side effects such as weight gain, hypertension, and diabetes.

Option D: Perform a synovial fluid aspiration and analysis: Synovial fluid aspiration and analysis may be performed in patients with suspected septic arthritis or other joint infections. In gout, synovial fluid analysis typically shows the presence of monosodium urate crystals. However, synovial fluid analysis is not necessary for the diagnosis of gout, which can usually be made based on the patient's clinical presentation and serum uric acid levels.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a history of bilateral upper and lower limb weakness for the past two hours. She has a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis. She is non-compliant with her medications. On examination, power is 2/5 in all the limbs. Babinski’s sign is upgoing bilaterally. The doctor is concerned about atlantoaxial joint instability. Which of the following is the most likely method to evaluate this patient’s atlantoaxial joint?

choices.text: Spine lateral view flexion and extension views

questions.solution:
Option A: Spine lateral view flexion and extension views

Rheumatoid arthritis:

  • Seen in young females, Bilateral hand pain
  • Morning stiffness
  • The most common area involved is the upper cervical spine
  • Craniovertebral junction involvement: RA> AS>Gout
  • Rheumatoid factor is positive
  • Elevated ESR and CRP.
  • A major cause of amyloidosis.
  • May results in osteopenia and osteoporosis.
  • C-C2 anomaly: Spine flexion/extension view
  • Deformities of RA: Swanneck deformity/ Boutonniere deformity.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) may lead to atlantoaxial instability.
  • Atlantoaxial instability (AAI)- excessive movement at the junction between the atlas (C1) and axis (C2) as a result of either a bony or ligamentous abnormality.
  • Neurologic symptoms occur when the spinal cord is involved and is upper motor neuron signs in limbs.
  • The assessment involves a flexion-extension lateral view of the cervical spine that can assess this instability. Flexion and extension views of the cervical spine often show subluxation at the atlantoaxial or mid-cervical levels.

Option B: Spine open-mouth view

  • Open mouth view is for atlantoaxial areas, specially dens but will not demonstrate instability.
  • Lateral spine view in extension and flexion position is a better position for atlantoaxial joint

Option C: Spine swimmer’s view

  • The swimmer’s view is for cervicothoracic junction assessment.

Option D: Spine Broden’s view

  • Broden’s view is for the subtalar joint.
  • For the atlantoaxial joint Lateral spine view in extension and flexion position is preferred.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old male presented with progressive pain and swelling in his left knee for the past 3 months. Physical examination revealed a firm, tender, and mildly swollen mass in the distal femur. X-ray showed:



MRI revealed a lesion with heterogeneous signal intensity in the distal femur, extending into the epiphysis and metaphysis. Which of the following is less likely a common site for metastasis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Regional lymph nodes are not a common site for osteosarcoma metastasis. Osteosarcoma is a malignant bone tumor that can spread to other parts of the body. However, regional lymph node metastasis is uncommon in osteosarcoma. This is because osteosarcoma cells typically spread through the bloodstream rather than through the lymphatic system.
  • Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures that are part of the lymphatic system, which helps to fight infections and diseases. Lymph nodes are connected by lymphatic vessels, which allow lymphatic fluid to flow from one node to another. Osteosarcoma cells are more likely to spread through the bloodstream, which allows them to bypass the lymph nodes and travel directly to other organs.
  • It's important to note that while regional lymph node metastasis is uncommon in osteosarcoma, it can still occur in some cases. This is more likely to happen in cases where the tumor is located near lymph nodes, such as in the pelvis or shoulder. If regional lymph node metastasis is suspected, imaging studies such as CT or MRI may be used to confirm the diagnosis.

Incorrect Choice: 
Option A: Lungs are the most common site for osteosarcoma metastasis. The lungs receive a high volume of blood flow, making it easy for malignant cells from the primary tumor to enter the bloodstream and travel to the lungs. Once in the lungs, osteosarcoma cells can establish new tumors and grow.

Option B: Liver is the second most common site for osteosarcoma metastasis. The liver receives a large amount of blood flow and is a common site for metastasis of many types of cancer. Once in the liver, osteosarcoma cells can establish new tumors and grow.

Option C: Bone marrow is also a common site for osteosarcoma metastasis. Osteosarcoma cells can invade the bone marrow and establish new tumors, leading to bone marrow involvement.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male has complained of progressive lower back pain and difficulty walking for six months. He also reports hearing loss and has noticed increased shoe size. On examination, he has a stooped posture, an antalgic gait, and tenderness over the lumbar spine. His neurological examination is unremarkable. 

Further investigations reveal elevated serum alkaline phosphatase, normal serum calcium and phosphate levels, and increased urinary hydroxyproline levels. Which of the following is /are characteristic feature(s) of the diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Paget disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodelling. It is a common condition in the elderly, and its aetiology is not fully understood. The disease can affect any bone in the body, but the most commonly affected bones are the pelvis, spine, skull, and femur. The clinical presentation of Paget disease can vary from asymptomatic to severe bone pain, deformity, and complications such as fractures, nerve compression, and osteosarcoma.
  • The bowing deformity of the femur is a characteristic feature of Paget's disease. Due to abnormal bone remodelling, the femur may become bowed and cause pain and functional impairment. Hearing loss is also a common feature of Paget's disease. The thickening of the temporal bone can compress the auditory nerve and lead to hearing loss.
  • Increased risk of osteosarcoma is a rare but well-known complication of Paget disease. It is estimated that 1-2% of patients with Paget disease will develop osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumour. Therefore, the correct answer is option D. 

Incorrect choices:  

Option A. Bowing femur deformity is a characteristic feature of Paget's disease. Due to abnormal bone remodelling, the femur may become bowed and cause pain and functional impairment. The femur is one of the commonly affected bones in Paget disease, and the abnormal bone remodelling can cause it to deform, resulting in a characteristic bowing appearance. The bowing deformity can lead to pain, decreased range of motion, and functional impairment.

  

Option B: Hearing loss is also a common feature of Paget's disease. Paget disease can affect the bones of the skull, including the temporal bone surrounding the inner ear. Thickening of the temporal bone can compress the auditory nerve and lead to hearing loss. The hearing loss in Paget disease is usually gradual and can affect both ears. It can range from mild to severe and significantly impact the patient's quality of life.

Option C: Increased risk of osteosarcoma is a characteristic feature of Paget's disease. Osteosarcoma is a type of bone cancer arising from osteoblasts forming new bone tissue. Although it is a rare complication of Paget disease, it is well-known and serious. In Paget disease, the abnormal bone remodelling process can lead to the formation of areas of weakened bone, which can subsequently progress to osteosarcoma. The estimated risk of developing osteosarcoma in patients with Paget disease is around 1-2%. The risk of developing osteosarcoma is higher in patients who have had Paget disease for a long time or have a family history.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man was hospitalized with a severe respiratory infection and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). A bacterial infection was suspected. In order to confirm it, the sample was studied under an electron microscope. While using the electron microscope, two chemicals, namely, glutaraldehyde and lead citrate, are used. In which of the following steps are these chemicals used respectively?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 

  • One of the most common forms of fixative used in electron microscopy is glutaraldehyde. It reacts with proteins and crosslinks them such that the structure is stabilized and no buffer extraction can occur. It is, therefore, used in the fixation step of electron microscopy. 

The other chemical is lead citrate, a heavy metal compound used as an enhancer in the staining step of electron microscopy.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: It is an incorrect choice because glutaraldehyde is a fixative used in the fixation step of electron microscopy. However, lead is not used in dehydration. The dehydration step includes the usage of alcohol.

Option B: It is an incorrect choice because the compounds used in the dehydration step of electron microscopy are alcohol, and in the embedding step are epoxy resins. Other forms, such as acrylic resins and liquid resins, are also used.

Option C: It is an incorrect choice because although lead citrate is used in the staining step, the compound used in the embedding step includes epoxy resins, acrylic resins, liquid resins, etc.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a fever, sore throat, and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the patient is found to have erythema and exudate on the tonsils. A throat swab is taken and sent for microbiological culture. The culture reveals the presence of Haemophilus influenzae. Which of the following virulence factors of H. influenzae is responsible for the patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

  • H. influenzae is a gram-negative bacterium that causes many infections, including otitis media, sinusitis, pneumonia, and meningitis. The virulence factors of H. influenzae include the capsule, lipooligosaccharide (LOS), and outer membrane proteins. 
  • The capsule is the most important virulence factor, allowing the bacterium to evade the host immune system and cause systemic infections. It also plays a role in the adherence of the bacterium to host cells.

Incorrect Choices: 
 

Option B: Endotoxin is a virulence factor of gram-negative bacteria, including H. influenzae. It is a component of the bacterial cell wall and can trigger an immune response in the host, leading to symptoms such as fever, chills, and shock.

Option C: Fimbriae are small, hair-like structures on the surface of bacteria that help them adhere to host cells. While H. influenzae does have fimbriae, they are not significant virulence factors.

Option D: Pili are longer and thicker than fimbriae and are involved in bacterial adherence. Like fimbriae, pili are not significant virulence factors of H. influenzae.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a severe bacterial infection. Hospital laboratory tests reveal that the bacteria causing the infection possess antibiotic-resistance genes. Upon further investigation, it was discovered that the patient recently underwent a dental procedure during which the dentist used a contaminated instrument. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for transferring antibiotic resistance genes between bacteria in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

  • Conjugation is the transfer of genetic material between two bacterial cells, either through the formation of a pilus or through direct cell-to-cell contact. The genetic material exchanged between the donor and recipient bacterial cells is often in the form of plasmid or transposon. 
  • Dental procedures can introduce bacteria into the bloodstream of humans through contaminated instruments or open wounds, potentially causing infection. If a pathogenic bacterium possessing antibiotic-resistance genes is present on a dental instrument, it could come in contact with another bacterium that is already present within the body of the patient and transfer those genes to it. This would result in an antibiotic-resistant infection.
  • Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Transformation is a mode of horizontal gene transfer involving a bacterial cell's uptake of free and naked DNA from the environment. This free DNA can include antibiotic-resistance genes. However, free DNA cannot exist in the environment for long. This makes it difficult to transfer genetic material through a transformation while a dental procedure is being conducted. 

Option B: Transduction is another mode of horizontal gene transfer in which the genetic material is transferred between bacteria via a bacteriophage, a virus that infects bacteria. This process cannot transfer a bacterium bearing antibiotic resistance genes from one bacterium to another without the presence of a bacteriophage virus that would most likely not contaminate dental equipment or instrument.

Option D: Mutation refers to a spontaneous change in the genomic sequence of a living organism or a virus. This phenomenon can create an antibiotic resistance gene. However, it cannot transfer such a gene or genes from one bacterium to another.

questions.text: The Holder pasteurisation method is widely used for preserving milk and other dairy products. In this method, the milk is heated at a specific temperature for a specific time to kill the pathogenic microorganisms present in it. Which of the following statements is true regarding the Holder method of pasteurisation?

choices.text: The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation depend on the type of microorganisms present in the milk.
The Holder method of pasteurisation is ineffective against all types of microorganisms in the milk.
The Holder method of pasteurisation is a type of sterilisation method that kills all microorganisms in the milk.
The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation are determined by the type of dairy product being pasteurised.

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • The Holder method of pasteurisation is a heat treatment process in which the milk is heated to a specific temperature for a specific time to kill the pathogenic microorganisms in it. French microbiologist Louis Pasteur developed this method in the 19th century.
  • The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation are determined by the type of microorganisms present in the milk. For example, the recommended temperature and heating time for pasteurising milk to kill Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, is 63°C for 30 minutes. However, for most other microorganisms, a temperature of 72°C for 15 seconds is sufficient for pasteurisation.
  • Despite its effectiveness against many pathogenic microorganisms, the Holder method of pasteurisation is ineffective against all types of microorganisms in the milk. Some heat-resistant microorganisms, such as Bacillus cereus and Bacillus stearothermophilus, can survive pasteurisation and grow rapidly in the milk, causing spoilage and foodborne illness.

Incorrect Choice: 

Option A:The statement "The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation depend on the type of microorganisms present in the milk" is incorrect. While it is true that the temperature and time of heating for pasteurisation vary depending on the type of microorganisms present in the milk, this variation is not due to the type of microorganisms themselves. Rather, it is due to the microorganisms’ heat resistance level. For example, spore-forming bacteria are more heat-resistant than non-spore-forming bacteria, so a higher temperature and longer heating time are required to kill them during pasteurisation.

Option C: The statement "The Holder method of pasteurisation is a type of sterilisation method that kills all microorganisms present in the milk" is incorrect. Pasteurisation is not a sterilisation method, as it does not kill all microorganisms present in the milk. Instead, it reduces the number of pathogenic microorganisms to a safe level while allowing some non-pathogenic microorganisms to survive.

Option D: The statement "The temperature and time of heating required for pasteurisation is determined by the type of dairy product being pasteurised" is partially correct. While the temperature and heating time for pasteurisation vary depending on the dairy product being pasteurised, this variation is not due to the type of dairy product itself. Rather, it is due to the level of heat resistance of the microorganisms present in the dairy product. For example, cream requires a higher temperature and longer heating time than milk due to its higher fat content.

questions.text:
A microbiology laboratory is testing the effectiveness of three different disinfectants against a strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The disinfectants are A, B, and C. The table below shows the results of the experiment.

 



	
		
		
		
		
	
	
		
			
			Disinfectant

			Contact time (min)
			
			
			Log reduction (CFU/mL)
			
		
		
			
			A

			10
			
			
			1.5
			
		
		
			
			A
			
			
			1:50
			
			
			10
			
			
			2.5
			
		
		
			
			A
			
			
			1:25
			
			
			10
			
			
			3.5
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			1:100
			
			
			5
			
			
			1.0
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			1:50
			
			
			5
			
			
			2.0
			
		
		
			
			B
			
			
			1:25
			
			
			5
			
			
			3.0
			
		
		
			
			C
			
			
			1:100
			
			
			30
			
			
			2.5
			
		
		
			
			C
			
			
			1:50
			
			
			30
			
			
			3.5
			
		
		
			
			C
			
			
			1:25
			
			
			30
			
			
			4.5
			
		
	


Which of the following disinfectants would be most effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa in a healthcare setting?

choices.text: Disinfectant A at 1:25 concentration for 5 min contact time
Disinfectant B at 1:50 concentration for 10 min contact time
Disinfectant C at 1:100 concentration for 5 min contact time
Disinfectant C at 1:25 concentration for 10 min contact time

questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • This experiment tested the effectiveness of three different disinfectants (A, B, and C) against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The disinfectants are tested at different concentrations and contact times, and the log reduction in CFU/mL is measured.
  • Disinfectant C is the most effective disinfectant against Pseudomonas aeruginosa in this experiment, with a log reduction of 4.5 at a concentration of 1:25 and a contact time of 30 minutes. Disinfectant A is less effective than disinfectant C, with a log reduction of only 3.5 at a concentration of 1:25 and a contact time of 10 minutes. Disinfectant B is the least effective disinfectant against Pseudomonas aeruginosa in this experiment, with a log reduction of only 3.0 at a concentration of 1:25 and a contact time of 5 minutes.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Disinfectant A at a concentration of 1:25 for 5 min contact time has a lower log reduction than disinfectant C.

Option B:  Disinfectant B at a concentration of 1:50 for 10 min contact time has a lower log reduction than disinfectant C.

Option C: Disinfectant C at a concentration of 1:100 for 5 min contact time has a lower log reduction than disinfectant C at a concentration of 1:25 for 10 min contact time.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male presents to the emergency department with fever, chills, and shortness of breath. His physical examination is significant for a temperature of 38.5°C, respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute, and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. A chest x-ray reveals bilateral pulmonary infiltrates and a sputum culture grows Klebsiella pneumoniae. 

Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3, with 85% neutrophils, a C-reactive protein (CRP) level of 150 mg/L, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 85 mm/hour. Based on these findings, which acute phase reactants are most likely to be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • Acute phase reactants are a group of proteins that are synthesized in the liver and other tissues in response to inflammation or infection. They include C-reactive protein (CRP), fibrinogen, haptoglobin, serum amyloid A (SAA), ceruloplasmin, and transferrin.
  • In this case, the patient presents with fever, chills, shortness of breath, and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, suggesting a respiratory tract infection. The sputum culture grows Klebsiella pneumoniae, a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia. The laboratory studies show an elevated white blood cell count with a neutrophil predominance and elevated CRP level; findings are consistent with an acute inflammatory response.
  • Fibrinogen is an acute-phase reactant synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation or tissue damage. It plays a critical role in the coagulation cascade and is converted to fibrin, forming a blood clot basis. In this case, the elevated fibrinogen level is likely due to the patient's acute inflammatory response and the risk of thrombosis associated with pneumonia.
     

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Haptoglobin is an acute phase reactant that binds to free haemoglobin released from damaged red blood cells. It is elevated in conditions associated with hemolysis, such as sickle cell disease, but is unlikely to be elevated in this patient with pneumonia.

Option B: Serum amyloid A (SAA) is an acute phase reactant synthesized by the liver in response to inflammation. It is elevated in various conditions, including infections, autoimmune diseases, and cancer. However, it is less specific than other acute phase reactants, and its elevation in this patient with pneumonia is less likely than other choices.

Option C: Ceruloplasmin is an acute phase reactant that plays a role in copper metabolism and antioxidant defence. It is elevated in conditions associated with oxidative stress, such as Wilson's disease, but is unlikely to be elevated in this patient with pneumonia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a high fever, vomiting, and a diffuse macular rash. She reports using a tampon for several days during her menstrual period. Blood cultures revealed the presence of Staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for her clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

The clinical presentation described in the case is consistent with toxic shock syndrome (TSS), a rare but potentially life-threatening complication of Staphylococcus aureus infection. TSS is caused by producing superantigens, bacterial toxins that can activate many T-cells and cause a systemic inflammatory response. The most common superantigen associated with TSS is toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), produced by certain strains of S. aureus. TSST-1 can cause fever, rash, hypotension, and multiple organ failure. 

Incorrect Choices:

Option A: Enterotoxin A is also produced by S. aureus but is not typically associated with TSS. 

Option B: Exfoliative toxin B is also produced by S. aureus but is not typically associated with TSS. 

Option D: Panton-Valentine leukocidin (PVL) is a toxin produced by some strains of S. aureus that are associated with severe skin and soft tissue infections, but it is not commonly associated with TSS.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with symptoms of shortness of breath, swelling of the face and lips, and hives all over his body. He reports that he recently started taking a new medication for his rheumatoid arthritis. Physical examination reveals tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypotension. The patient's medication is immediately stopped and treated with intravenous fluids, antihistamines, and corticosteroids. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is the patient most likely experiencing?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct. 

  • Anaphylaxis is a severe and potentially life-threatening type I hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by the rapid release of histamine and other mediators from mast cells and basophils, leading to systemic vasodilation, increased capillary permeability, and smooth muscle contraction. Symptoms of anaphylactic shock are shortness of breath, swelling of the face and lips, hives, tachycardia, and hypotension.
  • A person experiences anaphylactic shock when he/she gets exposed to an allergen, which in this case is the medication for rheumatoid arthritis. The patient in this case has developed an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity to the drug. Treatment for anaphylaxis typically involves stopping the offending agent and administering intravenous fluids, antihistamines, and corticosteroids.

Incorrect choices:

Option B: Type II hypersensitivity reactions involve binding IgG or IgM antibodies to antigens on cell surfaces, leading to complement activation and cell destruction. Type II hypersensitivity reaction triggers autoimmune disorders.

Option C: Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve the formation of immune complexes that deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. A unique feature of type III hypersensitivity is a high concentration of antibodies, specifically IgG, and low concentration of antigens.

Option D: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are delayed hypersensitivity reactions mediated by T cells. They typically occur 24-48 hours after exposure to an antigen and result in localized inflammation.

questions.text: A laboratory technician performed a bipolar gram staining procedure on a clinical sample obtained from a patient with suspected meningitis. After applying crystal violet, iodine, and alcohol, the technician observed that the bacteria in the sample appeared red-pink under the microscope. Which of the following statements best explains this observation?

choices.text: The bacteria are gram-negative and have a thick peptidoglycan layer
The bacteria are gram-positive and have a thin peptidoglycan layer
The bacteria are gram-negative and have a thin peptidoglycan layer
The bacteria are gram-positive and have a thick peptidoglycan layer

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Bipolar gram staining, also known as Ziehl-Neelsen staining, is a modification of the gram staining procedure used to detect bacteria with a waxy cell wall, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis and other acid-fast bacteria. 
  • Unlike the standard gram staining procedure, bipolar gram staining uses a strong decolorizing agent, such as acid-alcohol, to remove the crystal violet and iodine complex from non-acid-fast bacteria. In contrast, acid-fast bacteria retain the stain due to the high lipid content of their cell walls.
  • Therefore, in this case, the red-pink colour observed under the microscope indicates that the bacteria in the sample are gram-negative and have a thin peptidoglycan layer, as they could not retain the crystal violet and iodine complex after the decolorizing step. This observation is consistent with many bacteria that can cause meningitis, including Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Incorrect choices:
Option A: Gram-negative bacteria have a thin peptidoglycan layer. After the decolourising step, they cannot retain the crystal violet and iodine complex, resulting in a red-pink colour under the microscope.

Option B: Gram-positive bacteria have a thick peptidoglycan layer and retain the crystal violet and iodine complex after decolourising, resulting in a purple-blue colour under the microscope.

Option D: Gram-positive bacteria have a thick peptidoglycan layer and retain the crystal violet and iodine complex after decolourising, resulting in a purple-blue colour under the microscope.

questions.text: A 45-year-old diabetic patient presents to the hospital with a 2-week history of fever, headache, and blurred vision. On examination, he is found to have left-sided facial swelling and proptosis. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated blood sugar levels, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head and sinuses shows opacification of the left maxillary and ethmoid sinuses and a left-sided orbital apex lesion. A lesion biopsy reveals the presence of broad, aseptate hyphae with right-angle branching. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

  • The clinical presentation, laboratory investigations, and radiological findings are consistent with diagnosing rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. This rare but life-threatening fungal infection affects immunocompromised patients, particularly those with poorly controlled diabetes. 
  • The most common causative agent of mucormycosis is Mucorales spp., a filamentous fungi ubiquitous in the environment and found in soil, decaying organic matter, and contaminated water..

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Aspergillus fumigatus is a common cause of invasive aspergillosis, a fungal infection that typically affects patients with severe immunodeficiency or underlying lung disease. However, in this case, the clinical presentation and radiological findings are inconsistent with invasive aspergillosis.

Option B: Candida albicans is a yeast-like fungus commonly associated with superficial and invasive candidiasis, particularly in patients with prolonged antibiotic use, central venous catheters, and other medical devices. However, in this case, the clinical presentation and radiological findings are inconsistent with candidiasis.

Option C: Cryptococcus neoformans is a yeast-like fungus primarily responsible for cryptococcal meningitis, a fungal infection affecting patients with advanced HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunosuppression. However, in this case, the clinical presentation and radiological is inconsistent with cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with a painless, mobile, well-defined lump in her left breast. The lump is around 2 cm in size and has been increasing in size over the past few months. Ultrasound-guided biopsy of the lump revealed a fibroadenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.
Fibroadenomas are benign breast tumors that commonly occur in women of reproductive age. They are usually painless, mobile, and well-defined and can increase in size over time. The diagnosis of a fibroadenoma is made through ultrasound-guided biopsy.
Under circumstances where the patient has a history of breast cancer or when the fibroadenomas increase in size such that it starts to cause pain, discomfort, or anxiety, it is suggested to get the fibroadenomas surgically removed. Surgical excision of fibroadenomas depends on their size. In the case of large tumors, the preferred mode is through lumpectomy (an excision biopsy) or, in the case of small size vacuum-assisted excision biopsy.
Since the patient in concern has a 2cm fibroadenoma, surgical excision is the most appropriate management for this patient.

Incorrect choices:
Option A) Conservative management with a regular follow-up: Conservative management with regular follow-up is an option for small fibroadenomas (<1cm) that are confirmed by biopsy. However, in this case, the patient's fibroadenoma is larger than 2cm, which makes surgical excision a more appropriate option.

Option C) Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy is not recommended for the management of fibroadenomas as they are benign tumors and do not require such treatment. Radiation therapy is used for malignant tumors that have the potential to spread to other parts of the body.

Option D) Hormonal therapy: Hormonal therapy is not recommended for the management of fibroadenomas, as they are not hormone-dependent tumors. Hormonal therapy is used for hormone-dependent tumors, such as some types of breast cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a palpable breast lump. A core biopsy is performed, and the pathology report confirms invasive ductal carcinoma. The patient undergoes a lumpectomy with sentinel lymph node biopsy, and the final pathology report shows a 2.5 cm tumour with no lymph node involvement. Based on the TNM staging system, what is this patient’s breast cancer stage?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. 

According to the TNM staging system, the tumour size (T) for this patient is T2 (2.5 cm), the lymph node involvement (N) is N0 (no lymph node involvement), and there is no evidence of distant metastasis (M0). Based on this information, the patient’s breast cancer stage is IB.

Stage IB breast cancer is defined as a tumour larger than 0.5 cm but not larger than 2 cm without lymph node involvement or a tumour larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm without lymph node involvement. In this case, the tumour size is 2.5 cm, which falls within the size range for stage IB, and there is no lymph node involvement. Therefore, the correct answer is  Stage IB.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Stage IA breast cancer is defined as a tumour that is 2 cm or smaller with no lymph node involvement and no evidence of metastasis. This option is incorrect because the patient's tumour is larger than 2 cm.

Option C. Stage IIA breast cancer is defined as either a tumour larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm with no lymph node involvement or a tumour smaller than 2 cm with limited lymph node involvement (up to three axillary lymph nodes). This option is incorrect because the patient's tumour size is larger than 2 cm, but there is no lymph node involvement.

Option D. Stage IIB breast cancer is defined as either a tumour larger than 2 cm but not larger than 5 cm with limited lymph node involvement (up to three axillary lymph nodes) or a tumour larger than 5 cm with no lymph node involvement. This option is incorrect because the patient's tumour size is smaller than 5 cm, and there is no lymph node involvement.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old female presents with a history of weight gain, central obesity, moon face, and purple striae on her abdomen. Her blood pressure is elevated, and she has easy bruising. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated cortisol levels, and an MRI shows a pituitary adenoma.



What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Since the patient shows elevated levels of cortisol and an MRI with pituitary adenoma, it can be assumed that the patient's clinical presentation is consistent with Cushing Syndrome, which is caused by excess cortisol secretion. The most common cause of Cushing Syndrome is a pituitary adenoma, which leads to excess production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and subsequent cortisol secretion.
  • The treatment of Cushing syndrome depends on its cause and source of it. In the present scenario, it is observed that the cause of the patient's Cushing Syndrome is a pituitary adenoma; therefore, the appropriate management of this patient would be Pituitary surgery. It is the treatment of choice for Cushing Syndrome caused by a pituitary adenoma. The aim of surgery is to remove the tumor and normalize cortisol levels. If the tumor cannot be completely removed, radiation therapy may be considered to reduce tumor size and cortisol secretion.

Incorrect choices:
Option A) Adrenalectomy: It is the treatment of choice for Cushing Syndrome caused by an adrenal tumor, but it is not appropriate for this patient as she has a pituitary adenoma. In this case, the source of excess cortisol production is from the pituitary adenoma and not from the adrenal gland.
Option C) Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy may be considered in patients who have residual disease after surgery or who are not candidates for surgery. However, it is not the first-line treatment for Cushing Syndrome caused by a pituitary adenoma and should only be considered if surgery is not feasible or if there is a residual disease after surgery.
Option D) Medical management with cortisol-lowering agents: These agents may be used to control symptoms in patients who are not candidates for surgery, but it is not curative and has significant side effects. Additionally, in this case, the patient has a pituitary adenoma, which is causing excess cortisol production, and not an adrenal tumor, which would be the target of cortisol-lowering agents. Therefore, medical management is not the most appropriate treatment option for this patient.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with hypertension, headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis. Further evaluation reveals an adrenal mass and laboratory tests demonstrate elevated levels of metanephrines and catecholamines. What is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the adrenal mass

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumour that arises from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla and can lead to excess production of catecholamines, such as epinephrine and norepinephrine. 
  • Patients with pheochromocytoma may present with symptoms such as hypertension, headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis.
  • Elevated levels of metanephrines and catecholamines on laboratory testing can confirm the diagnosis.

The initial management of pheochromocytoma involves alpha-adrenergic blockade to control blood pressure and prevent a hypertensive crisis. This is typically achieved with medications such as phenoxybenzamine or doxazosin. Once the blood pressure is under control, beta-adrenergic blockade may be added to prevent tachycardia and arrhythmias.

Surgical resection of the adrenal mass is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma, but it should only be performed after adequate alpha-adrenergic blockade to avoid perioperative complications such as hypertensive crisis. Observation and follow-up imaging are not appropriate management options for pheochromocytoma, as the tumour has the potential to grow and cause complications such as malignant hypertension, stroke, and myocardial infarction.


Incorrect choices:
Option A. Surgical resection of the adrenal mass: Although surgical resection is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma, it should only be performed after adequate alpha-adrenergic blockade to prevent perioperative complications.

Option C. Beta-adrenergic blockade: Beta-adrenergic blockade may be used in addition to the alpha-adrenergic blockade to prevent tachycardia and arrhythmias, but it should not be used as initial management, as it can worsen hypertension.

Option D. Observation and follow-up imaging: Pheochromocytoma has the potential to grow and cause complications, and observation and follow-up imaging are not appropriate management options.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a dry cough, shortness of breath, and fever. Imaging reveals bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease. Further investigation reveals non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct. 

The patient's presentation and imaging findings are consistent with sarcoidosis, characterized by non-caseating granulomas. Corticosteroids are the first-line treatment for sarcoidosis that effectively reduce granuloma formation and improve symptoms. Methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, mycophenolate mofetil, and azathioprine are alternative treatments that may be used in refractory cases or in patients who cannot tolerate corticosteroids. However, still, they are not the initial treatment of choice.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Methotrexate is an immunosuppressive often used to treatment of autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis and psoriasis. While it may be used to treat sarcoidosis, it is not the initial treatment of choice.

Option C. Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is used in the treatment of cancer and autoimmune diseases. While it may be used to treat sarcoidosis, it is not the initial treatment of choice.

Option D. Mycophenolate mofetil is an immunosuppressive drug that is often used in the prevention of organ transplant rejection and the treatment of autoimmune diseases.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old infant presents to the clinic with a large, painless mass on the left side of the neck. Upon examination, the mass is found to be a cystic hygroma. The parents are concerned about the potential complications and ask about the management options. 
Consider the following statements.


	Surgery is the first-line treatment for cystic hygroma.
	Sclerotherapy is a potential treatment option for cystic hygroma.
	Radiotherapy is a potential treatment option for cystic hygroma.
	Aspiration of the cystic hygroma is the preferred initial management strategy.
	Cystic hygromas are always benign and do not require any treatment.
	Cystic hygromas are commonly associated with chromosomal abnormalities such as Turner syndrome.


Which of the following statements is/are true regarding managing cystic hygroma?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

  • A cystic hygroma is a lymphatic malformation typically present at birth or developing in early childhood. It is a benign tumour that arises from lymphatic tissue and is most commonly located in the neck but can also occur in other parts of the body. Cystic hygromas can cause disfigurement, airway obstruction, and difficulty swallowing, depending on their location and size.
  • The management of cystic hygroma depends on several factors, including the lesion's location, size, and symptoms. Sclerotherapy is a potential treatment option for cystic hygroma, especially for lesions that are difficult to access surgically or are located in critical areas, such as the head and neck. Sclerotherapy involves injecting a sclerosing agent into the cystic hygroma, which causes the tissue to shrink and eventually disappear.
  • Radiotherapy is another potential treatment option for cystic hygroma, especially for cases where surgery or sclerotherapy is not feasible or failed. Radiotherapy involves using high-energy radiation to destroy the tumour cells, which can significantly reduce the size of the cystic hygroma.
  • Therefore, statements 2, 3 and 6 are true. Hence, option A is correct.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Surgery is often considered the first-line treatment option for cystic hygroma, but it is not always necessary, especially in cases where the lesion is small and asymptomatic.

Option C. Aspiration of the cystic hygroma is not recommended as the preferred initial management strategy because it can lead to the recurrence of the lesion and increase the risk of infection.

Option D. Cystic hygromas are not always benign and can be associated with chromosomal abnormalities, such as Turner syndrome. Therefore, a thorough patient evaluation should be performed to rule out any underlying genetic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient with a history of parotidectomy was brought to a clinic with symptoms like redness around the cheek area accompanied by sweating and itching. Later he was diagnosed with Dupuy's syndrome. Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

  • Dupuy's syndrome is another name for Frey's syndrome. It is a condition that occurs following parotidectomy (removal of the parotid gland, either complete or partial), where there is aberrant regeneration of parasympathetic nerve fibers to sweat glands instead of salivary glands. This results in sweating and flushing over the affected area during meals, which can be socially embarrassing for the patient.
  • The most appropriate management for Frey's syndrome is an injection of botulinum toxin, which blocks the release of acetylcholine and prevents sweating. An injection of botulinum toxin A is given locally in the affected area. It reduces the severity of symptoms in the patient and is preferred as it is a minimally invasive procedure that has no side effects. Generally, injections of botulinum toxin are administered repeatedly in patients with Frey syndrome in order to improve results.

Incorrect choices:
Option A) Observation and reassurance: It is an incorrect choice because observation and reassurance do not address the underlying pathophysiology of the condition.
Option B) Topical application of antiperspirants: It is not the most appropriate management for Frey's syndrome, as antiperspirants are not effective in treating aberrant nerve regeneration.
Option D) Surgical transection: Although surgical transection of nerve fibers such as tympanic nerve, auricular nerve, and auriculotemporal nerve may be considered a form of treatment for Frey's syndrome, it is a temporary treatment and not commonly practiced. Thus, it won't be appropriate management.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department following a physical altercation. The patient complains of severe pain and swelling around the midface region. Upon examination, the patient is found to have a complex facial fracture that involves the Le Forte II fracture and an orbital floor fracture. Which of the following is a potential complication associated with this type of complex facial fracture?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • A complex facial fracture involving Le Forte II and orbital floor fractures can lead to serious complications. Le Forte II fracture involves the separation of the maxilla and the hard palate from the rest of the skull, while orbital floor fracture involves the fracture of the bony floor of the eye socket. This combination of fractures can cause a herniation of the orbital contents into the maxillary sinus, leading to enophthalmos, diplopia, and facial asymmetry.
  • In addition, orbital floor fractures can cause CSF leakage, which can present as rhinorrhea, otorrhea, or halo sign. The halo sign is a classic sign of CSF leakage, where the fluid is collected on a white background, such as a gauze, and appears as a clear halo around the fluid. Therefore, the correct answer is option B.


Incorrect choices:
 
Option A. Corneal abrasion is a potential complication of orbital fractures, but this option does not specify the involvement of the orbital floor fracture, a distinguishing feature of the given complex facial fracture.
 
Option C. Hearing loss is not a common complication associated with complex facial fractures involving Le Forte II fracture and orbital floor fracture.
 
Option D. Nasal septal perforation is a potential complication of Le Forte I fracture, where the fracture line passes through the nasal septum, but this option does not specify the involvement of Le Forte II fracture and orbital floor fracture, which is the given complex facial fracture in this question.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient presents with trismus and progressive difficulty in opening his mouth. He has a long-standing history of tobacco and betel nut chewing. On examination, he has a fibrotic band in the buccal mucosa and limited mouth opening. 



Which of the following is the most appropriate management for this condition?

choices.text: Surgical excision of the fibrotic band
Betel nut cessation and supportive care
Combination therapy with pentoxifylline and tocopherol

questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

  • Oral submucous fibrosis (OSF) is a chronic, progressive disease commonly seen in individuals who chew tobacco or betel nuts. The disease is characterized by the deposition of collagen fibers in the submucosa of the oral cavity, which results in a fibrotic band that restricts mouth opening (trismus) and can lead to dysphagia.
  • Since OSF is potentially a malignant disorder, the most appropriate management for OSF is surgical excision of the fibrotic band. This procedure can be performed under local anesthesia and involves the removal of the fibrotic tissue either with the help of a scalpel or through a laser. In order to maintain the oral opening, surgical excision is often followed by interposition grafts. It is the preferred mode because it helps check the malignancy, improves the opening of the mouth, and alleviates other symptoms.


Incorrect choices:

Option A) Topical corticosteroids: These may be used in the management of mild cases of OSF but are not effective in treating the fibrotic band or improving mouth opening in advanced cases.

Option C) Betel nut cessation and supportive care: It is important in the management of OSF, as continued use of betel nuts can worsen the condition. However, this alone is insufficient in treating the fibrotic band or improving mouth opening. Cessation of betel nut can also be considered a mode of prevention concerning OSF.

Option D) Combination therapy with pentoxifylline and tocopherol: This method has been shown to have some benefits in improving symptoms and reducing the progression of OSF. However, its effectiveness is not considered the most effective management strategy for advanced cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the surgical clinic complaining of leg pain, heaviness, and swelling. On examination, the patient has visibly enlarged veins in her legs, with the largest one measuring approximately 5mm in diameter.
