However, this condition does not present with the same symptoms as PCOS and does not typically cause elevated levels of androgens. Hence, this option is incorrect.
 
Option D. CAH is a genetic disorder that affects the adrenal glands, leading to excessive androgen production. However, patients with CAH typically present with external genitalia abnormalities, and the patient in this scenario denies excessive facial hair or other physical symptoms. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for a routine Pap smear. Her Pap smear is positive for high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) types. She reports no symptoms and has no significant past medical history. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct 
 
This patient has a positive Pap smear for high-risk HPV types, which are associated with an increased risk of cervical cancer. Management of HPV infection depends on the patient's age, HPV status, and the presence or absence of abnormal cervical cytology.
Referral for colposcopy is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient, as it allows for visualization and biopsy of any abnormal cervical lesions. If colposcopy shows no evidence of dysplasia, the patient can be followed up with routine Pap smears at recommended intervals. Thehe patient will require further evaluation and treatme if colposcopy reveals dysplasia or cervical cancernt.
 
Incorrect choices:
 
Option A: Pap smear is a procedure where cells are gently removed from the cervix with the help of a brush and checked under a microscope for cervical cancer. A repeat Pap smear in 6 months may be appropriate for low-risk HPV types or mild dysplasia. However, in this case, the patient has high-risk HPV types, which warrants further evaluation.
 
Option C: HPV genotyping may be useful in identifying specific high-risk HPV types, but it does not change management in this case. HPV genotyping test is usually used to detect the presence of HPV 16 and 18. These are the strain that is associated with cancer. 
 
Option D: Administration of the HPV vaccine is recommended for HPV prevention, but it does not change management in this patient who is already infected. HPV vaccination is mainly administered to both girls and boys to prevent cancer-causing infection. Thus, it is a step administered for prevention, not management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with vaginal and post-coital bleeding for the last two months. She has a history of irregular menstrual periods; her history of sexual partners wasn't disclosed. On pelvic examination, cervical growth is noted. A biopsy of the lesion confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. Which of the following statements about cervical cancer is correct?

choices.text: Most common site for cancer cervix is Squamo columnar junction.
Most common site for cancer cervix is Transformation Zone.
Cervical cancer screening should be started at age 40 in women with no risk factors.
The most common histological type of cervical cancer is adenocarcinoma.

questions.solution:
Option B is correct 

  • Most common site for cancer cervix is Transformation Zone > Sqauamo columnar junction.
  • The transformation zone is an area in the cervix where the columnar epithelium of the endocervix meets the squamous epithelium of the exocervix.

Incorrect Choices:
 
Option A: Squamo columnar junction is also the site for Cervical Cancer but not the most common.

  • Most common site for cancer cervix is Transformation Zone > Sqauamo columnar junction.

 
Option C: Cervical cancer screening should be started at age 21 years in women, regardless of risk factors. The screening frequency and starting age may vary depending on the individual's risk factors. Still, it is generally recommended to start screening at an earlier age in women with risk factors such as multiple sexual partners, a history of sexually transmitted infections, or a compromised immune system.
 
Option D: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common histological type of cervical cancer, accounting for around 80-90% of cases. Adenocarcinoma is less common, accounting for approximately 10-20% of cases.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. She reports having regular menstrual cycles and no significant past medical history. Pelvic examination reveals an enlarged uterus. Transvaginal ultrasound shows multiple uterine fibroids. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct
 
Treatment options for uterine fibroids depend on the severity of symptoms, the size and number of fibroids, and the patient's reproductive plans. 
Myomectomy is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient, as it involves the surgical removal of fibroids along with preserving the uterus. 
Myomectomy can be performed depending on the size, number, and location of fibroids. This approach is recommended for patients who desire future fertility or wish to preserve their uterus.
 
Incorrect choices:

Option A: Observation and monitoring of symptoms may be appropriate for asymptomatic patients or those with mild symptoms. However, in this case, the patient is experiencing significant symptoms and an enlarged uterus, suggesting a need for more aggressive management.
 
Option B: Medical management with hormonal therapy may be effective in reducing the size of fibroids and alleviating symptoms in some patients. However, it is typically not recommended for long-term use and may not be effective for larger fibroids.
 
Option C: Hysteroscopy with resection of fibroids may be appropriate for patients with submucosal fibroids (fibroids located inside the uterine cavity). However, in this case, the patient has multiple uterine fibroids, which are not amenable to hysteroscopic resection.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with complaints of urine leakage from her vagina for the past 6 months. She reports a history of a complicated vaginal delivery 15 years ago, with a prolonged second stage of labor and the use of forceps. On physical examination, there is evidence of urine in the vaginal vault, and a urine dipstick test is positive for the presence of leukocytes and nitrites. Which of the following diagnosis is most likely appropriate for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct 
 
Vesicovaginal fistulas are abnormal connections between the bladder and the vagina, which can lead to urinary leakage from the vagina. A variety of factors, including obstetric trauma, radiation therapy, and surgery, can cause them. In this scenario, the patient's history of a complicated vaginal delivery with forceps suggests obstetric trauma as the cause of her vesicovaginal fistula. The positive urine dipstick test suggests a urinary tract infection, a common complication of vesicovaginal fistulas.
 
Incorrect Choices:
 
Option B: Ureterovaginal fistulas are abnormal connections between the ureter and the vagina, which can lead to urinary leakage from the vagina. They are a much less common type of fistula than vesicovaginal fistulas and are typically caused by surgical trauma or radiation therapy.
 
Option C: Rectovaginal fistulas are abnormal connections between the rectum and the vagina, which can lead to fecal material in the vagina. They are not typically associated with urinary leakage.
 
Option D: Urinary incontinence is a common condition that can cause urine leakage, but it is not typically associated with the presence of urine in the vaginal vault or positive urine dipstick test results. Various factors, like weak pelvic muscles, nerve damage, and hormonal changes, can cause it.

questions.text: A 28-year-old sexually active female with a history of taking OCPs comes to the clinic with complaints of vaginal pruritis and thick curd-like vaginal discharge. On per vaginal examination, there were creamy white plaques. Which of the following STD treatment kits should be used for the management of the patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct

A sexually active female with a history of OCPs presenting with thick curd-like discharge suggests a diagnosis of fungal infection candida vaginitis. The creamy white plaques are due to the organism Candida species. So green kit or Kit 2 will be used for the management of the patient. The green kit comprises of tab secnidazole 2g and tab fluconazole 150mg.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: The gray kit or Kit 1 is used for urethral Anorectal (anus and rectum) or cervical discharge. It comprises of tab azithromycin 1g and tab cefixime 400 mg.

Option C: The yellow Kit or Kit 6 is used for lower abdominal pain caused by pelvic inflammatory diseases. It comprises of tab cefixime 400mg, tab metronidazole 400mg, and tab doxycycline 100 mg.

Option D: The black kit or Kit 7 is used for inguinal bubo, which is lymph node enlargement in the groin area. It comprises of tab azithromycin 1g and tab doxycycline 100mg.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of amenorrhea and difficulty breastfeeding. She had a postpartum haemorrhage during delivery and required blood transfusions. On examination, she was found to have low blood pressure and a pale complexion. Laboratory tests reveal low levels of all anterior pituitary hormones. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

The patient's symptoms of amenorrhea, difficulty breastfeeding, low blood pressure, and pale complexion suggest Sheehan syndrome as the most likely diagnosis. 

Sheehan syndrome is a condition that occurs due to postpartum pituitary necrosis causing a reduction in the size of the pituitary gland. This results in the loss of pituitary function, leading to hormonal deficiencies. Commonly affected hormones include thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), luteinizing hormone (LH), and growth hormone (GH).

Incorrect Choices:
 
Option A. Cushing's syndrome is caused by increased cortisol levels, resulting in symptoms such as weight gain, facial swelling, and abnormal fat deposition. This condition is not associated with postpartum haemorrhage or difficulty breastfeeding. Hence, this option is incorrect.
 
Option B. Addison's disease is caused by decreased production of adrenal hormones, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, weight loss, and low blood pressure. However, this condition does not affect the pituitary gland and does not result from postpartum haemorrhage. Therefore, this option is incorrect.
 
Option C. Pituitary apoplexy is when the pituitary gland suddenly bleeds or loses blood supply, causing severe headaches, vision changes, and altered mental status. This condition does not have the same symptoms as Sheehan syndrome and is not caused by postpartum haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with infertility. She has regular menstrual cycles and no significant past medical history. Pelvic examination and transvaginal ultrasound are normal. Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) reveals a unicornuate uterus with a single patent fallopian tube. Which of the following accounts for this finding the most likely?

choices.text: Congenital absence of one fallopian tube
Pelvic adhesions leading to tubal occlusion

questions.solution:
Option C is correct.

This scenario presents a case of infertility with an abnormality detected on a hysterosalpingogram (HSG). Hysterosalpingogram is an imaging treatment called used to determine the reasons female infertility occurs. In this method, radiopaque dye is injected into the uterus and the result is shown on an x-ray. 

The HSG shows a unicornuate uterus with a single patent fallopian tube. The most likely explanation for this finding is a congenital uterine anomaly. A unicornuate uterus is a type of uterine anomaly in which one Mullerian duct fails to develop, leading to a single uterine horn and a single fallopian tube on one side.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Non-fusion of Müllerian ducts is incorrect because the failure of the Mullerian ducts to fuse would result in a complete uterine septum rather than a unicornuate uterus.

Option B: Congenital absence of one fallopian tube is incorrect because a unicornuate uterus with a single patent fallopian tube indicates the presence of one fallopian tube.

Option D: Pelvic adhesions leading to tubal occlusion is incorrect because the HSG shows a patent fallopian tube, indicating no tubal occlusion.

questions.text: Which structures provide the primary support for the uterus?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.
 
The cardinal ligaments play an important role in supporting the uterus and maintaining its position within the pelvis. The cardinal ligaments are paired structures that originate from the lateral wall of the pelvis and attach to the cervix and upper part of the vagina. They are also known as the transverse cervical ligaments or Mackenrodt's ligaments. 

The superior part of the cardinal ligament is composed of fibrous tissue, while the inferior part contains smooth muscle. The cardinal ligament is one of the major ligaments of the uterus, formed as a thickening of connective tissue at the base of the broad ligament of the uterus.
 
Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Round ligament: This option is incorrect because while the round ligament does provide support to the uterus, it is not the primary support structure. The round ligament runs from the uterus to the labia majora, helping to prevent the uterus from moving too far forward.
 
Option B. Uterosacral ligament: This option is incorrect because while the uterosacral ligament does provide support to the uterus, it is not the primary support structure. The uterosacral ligaments attach the uterus to the sacrum, helping to prevent it from moving too far backwards.
 
Option C. Broad ligament: This option is incorrect because while the broad ligament does provide support to the uterus, it is not the primary support structure. The broad ligament attaches the uterus to the pelvic walls and floor and supports the ovaries by suspending them from the uterine cornua.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks gestation. On pelvic examination, she has a bluish-purple discoloration of the cervix. What is the most likely explanation for this finding?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

Chadwick's sign is a bluish-purple discolouration of the cervix, vagina, and vulva that occurs in early pregnancy due to increased vascularity and congestion of the pelvic organs. This sign is usually visible at 6-8 weeks of gestation and is one of the earliest signs of pregnancy. It can also occur in the first trimester of pregnancy due to increased blood flow and engorgement of the cervix, uterus, and vagina.

In this scenario, the patient's presentation of vaginal bleeding at 12 weeks gestation is concerning for a threatened miscarriage or a possible cervical ectopic pregnancy. However, the presence of Chadwick's sign indicates that the bleeding is likely due to early pregnancy-related changes rather than a pathological condition such as cervical cancer or infection. Therefore, the correct answer is the Chadwick sign.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Osiander’s sign is seen at the 8th week of pregnacny. There is increased pulsations felt through the lateral fornices.

Option B. Palmer sign is the regular and rhythmic uterine contraction can be detected by bimanual examination. it is seen between 4 - 8 weeks.

Option C. Goodell’s sign is the softening of cervix and bluish discoloration of cervix. it is seen at 6th week of pregnancy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of pelvic inflammatory disease presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She is hemodynamically stable. Her serum beta-hCG is positive, and transvaginal ultrasound shows a 2-cm adnexal mass. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct 

An ectopic pregnancy is a form of pregnancy where the fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. Risk factors for ectopic pregnancy include previous pelvic inflammatory disease, tubal surgery, and in vitro fertilization. The classic presentation of ectopic pregnancy is abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding in a woman of reproductive age with a positive pregnancy test.

Incorrect choices:

Option B: On ultrasound, ovarian torsion can present with similar symptoms, including severe abdominal pain and adnexal mass. However, ovarian torsion typically occurs in women of reproductive age without a positive pregnancy test.

Option C: On ultrasound, a tubo-ovarian abscess can present with similar symptoms, including abdominal pain and adnexal mass. However, patients with a tubo-ovarian abscess may have a fever and leukocytosis, which are not typically seen in ectopic pregnancy.

Option D: On ultrasound, the Corpus luteum cyst can present with similar symptoms, including abdominal pain and adnexal mass. However, corpus luteum cysts are typically smaller than 2 cm and resolve spontaneously within a few weeks. In addition, corpus luteum cysts are not associated with vaginal bleeding or a positive pregnancy test.

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman presents for genetic counseling. Her non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) reveals an increased risk for trisomy 21. A diagnostic test is recommended, and chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed at 13 weeks of gestation. The CVS results are normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the discrepancy between the NIPT and CVS results?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Mosaicism is the most likely explanation for the discrepancy between the NIPT and CVS results. Mosaicism occurs when two or more cell populations have different genetic makeup in an individual. In the case of trisomy 21, a mosaic individual would have some cells with an extra copy of chromosome 21 and some cells with the normal number of chromosomes. 

NIPT analyzes cell-free DNA from the placenta and can detect trisomies in the placental cells, which may not reflect the fetal genotype. CVS analyzes fetal cells directly and can detect mosaicism that NIPT may not detect.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Maternal mosaicism is a rare condition in which the mother has two or more cell populations with different genetic makeup. Maternal mosaicism can cause false-positive NIPT results, but it is not likely to cause a normal CVS result in this scenario.

Option C. Vanishing twin syndrome occurs when one fetus in a multiple gestation pregnancies dies in utero and is reabsorbed. This can cause false-positive NIPT results if the DNA from the dead fetus is detected in the mother's blood, but it is not likely to cause a normal CVS result in this scenario.

Option D. Laboratory error is always possible in any diagnostic test, but it is unlikely to be the sole explanation for the discrepancy between the NIPT and CVS results. A repeat test may be recommended to confirm the results, but further investigation is needed to identify the underlying cause of the discrepancy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents at 32 weeks of gestation with sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding. The fetal heart rate is normal on examination, and there is no evidence of uterine contractions. Which of the subsequent diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

Painless vaginal bleeding in the third trimester is a concerning symptom and should prompt immediate evaluation for placenta previa. Placenta previa is a condition that occurs during pregnancy when the placenta implants in the lower part of the uterus, partially or completely covering the internal os of the cervix. 

In placenta pervia, the placenta's detachment from the uterine wall might cause painless vaginal bleeding. However, fetal heart rate is typically normal in placenta previa until late in the condition.

Incorrect Choices:

Option B. Abruptio placentae is another condition that can cause vaginal bleeding in the third trimester. However, it is typically associated with painful uterine contractions and fetal distress due to the separation of the placenta from the uterine wall. The fetal heart rate may be abnormal in abruptio placentae.

Option C. Uterine rupture is a rare but serious complication of pregnancy that can cause vaginal bleeding and fetal distress. It is typically associated with a history of prior uterine surgery or trauma. In this scenario, there is no evidence of uterine contractions, which makes uterine rupture less likely.

Option D. Cervical polyps are benign growths that can occur on the cervix and cause vaginal bleeding in pregnancy. However, they are typically associated with minimal bleeding and do not cause sudden onset of painless bleeding in the third trimester.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman presents for routine prenatal care at 28 weeks gestation. Ultrasound reveals fetal hydrops with pericardial and pleural effusions, ascites, and skin edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of fetal hydrops in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct.

In this scenario, the most likely cause of fetal hydrops is fetal anemia, possibly due to Rh isoimmunization, ABO incompatibility, or other hemolytic disorders. The anemia increases fetal erythropoietin production and subsequent fluid accumulation in fetal tissues.

Hydrops fetalis is a serious condition where excess fluid accumulates in the fetus, leading to swelling of the body tissues and cavities. Various factors, including fetal anemia, maternal diabetes, maternal hypertension, and maternal infection, can cause fetal hydrops.

Incorrect Choices:

Option A. Maternal diabetes can cause fetal macrosomia, respiratory distress syndrome, and other complications, but it is not typically associated with fetal hydrops.

Option B. Maternal hypertension can lead to fetal growth restriction, preterm birth, and other complications, but it is not typically associated with fetal hydrops.

Option C. Maternal infection can cause fetal inflammation, preterm birth, and other complications, but it is not typically associated with fetal hydrops. However, in rare cases, fetal infections such as parvovirus B19 can cause fetal hydrops.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks gestation presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe headache, visual changes, and abdominal pain. She has a history of gestational hypertension that has been managed with bed rest and close monitoring. Her blood pressure on admission is 160/100 mmHg, and her urine dipstick is positive for protein. Her laboratory results are significant for thrombocytopenia and elevated liver enzymes. She eventually has a seizure in the emergency department. Which of the following initial management seems most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A is correct 
 
This patient is presenting with signs and symptoms consistent with eclampsia, a severe complication of pregnancy-induced hypertension. The most appropriate initial management for this patient is administering magnesium sulfate to prevent further seizures and protect the patient from neurologic damage. Magnesium sulfate is the drug of choice for preventing seizures in eclampsia.
 
Incorrect choices:
 
Option B: Perform an emergent cesarean section: While delivery is the definitive treatment for eclampsia, performing an emergent cesarean section is not the most appropriate initial management for this patient. Stabilization of the mother's condition with magnesium sulfate is the priority.
 
Option C: Administer labetalol: Labetalol is a medication used to control blood pressure in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. However, in eclampsia, the priority is to prevent seizures with magnesium sulfate. Blood pressure control can be addressed after the patient is stabilized.
 
Option D: Administer hydralazine: Hydralazine is another medication used to control blood pressure in hypertensive disorders of pregnancy. However, in eclampsia, the priority is to prevent seizures with magnesium sulfate. Blood pressure control can be addressed after the patient is stabilized.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with a fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis followed by a maculopapular rash, starting from the face and then spreading to the trunk and extremities. The rash lasted for about 5-6 days, and the child recovered completely. Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis of this condition?

choices.text: A throat swab is necessary for the diagnosis of this condition
IgM antibody testing is the gold standard for the diagnosis of this condition
A positive serology is required for the diagnosis of this condition
Clinical features and a history of contact with a confirmed case are sufficient for the diagnosis of this condition.

questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 

Clinical features and a history of contact with a confirmed case are sufficient for the diagnosis of measles. Laboratory tests such as throat swabs or serology can be used to confirm the diagnosis, but they are not always necessary.
The clinical features described in the question stem are classic for measles. Measles is a viral illness caused by the measles virus and is highly contagious. The diagnosis of measles is primarily based on clinical features, such as fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and maculopapular rash, which starts from the face and then spreads to the trunk and extremities. A history of contact with a confirmed case of measles is also helpful in making the diagnosis. 

Incorrect choices:

Option A. This option is incorrect because a throat swab is not necessary for the diagnosis of measles. Throat swabs can be used to confirm the diagnosis by detecting the presence of the measles virus, but they are not always necessary.

Option B. This option is incorrect because although IgM antibody testing can be used to confirm the diagnosis of measles, it is not considered the gold standard for diagnosis. The gold standard for diagnosis of measles is the presence of clinical features, such as fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and maculopapular rash, which start from the face and then spread to the trunk and extremities, along with a history of contact with a confirmed case.

Option C. This option is incorrect because a positive serology is not required for the diagnosis of measles. Serology testing can be used to confirm the diagnosis by detecting the presence of specific antibodies against the measles virus, but it is not always necessary.

questions.text: A rural PHC senior doctor asked his interns to prepare various charts and diagrams in order to guide and create awareness among the villagers. Identify the Logo shown in the Photograph below?
questions.solution:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy from a rural area was brought to a primary health center for a routine health check-up. The healthcare worker who examined the child noticed that he was not able to hear properly and also had a visible cleft palate. The healthcare worker informed the child's parents about the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) and advised them to take the child for screening under the program. Which of the following statements is true regarding RBSK in this case?

choices.text: RBSK is a program initiated by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide comprehensive healthcare services to children under the age of 5 years
RBSK provides screening for 30 health conditions, including physical, cognitive, sensory, and social disabilities
RBSK services are available only in private hospitals and clinics.
RBSK is not applicable to children living in rural areas

questions.solution:
Option B is correct. 
 
RBSK is a program initiated by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare to provide comprehensive healthcare services to children under the age of 18 years. The program provides screening for 30 health conditions, including physical, cognitive, sensory, and social disabilities. Therefore, this option is correct as it states that RBSK provides screening for multiple health conditions, including those mentioned in the case of the 7-year-old boy with hearing impairment and cleft palate.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. This option is incorrect because RBSK provides healthcare services to children under 18 years and not just up to the age of 5 years.

Option C. This option is incorrect because RBSK services are provided free of cost in government hospitals and clinics. Private hospitals and clinics are not covered under the program.

Option D. This option is incorrect because RBSK applies to all children regardless of their residence, whether rural or urban. The program aims to provide comprehensive healthcare services to all children under 18 years in India.

questions.text: DALYs is Disability adjusted life years and it is the best indicator of ‘’disease Burden''. What is the MCC of DALYs lost among Mental health disorders?
questions.solution:
MCC of DALYs lost among Mental health disorders is Unipolar Depression.

DALY→ Disability adjusted life years

- It is best indicator of ‘’ disease Burden ‘’

- M/C mental health disorder is unipolar depression

- DALY'S lost d/t unipolar depression = 64,963 [1400 DALY'S lost / 1,00,000 population]

- M/C mental health disorder resulting in death is → Alzheimer’s & dementias

- MC substance abused - Tobacco

- MC Narcotic substance abused - cannabis

- Mental morbidity = 18-20/1000 population.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented to the clinic with symptoms of fever, malaise, and cough for two weeks. She has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. On examination, she had enlarged cervical lymph nodes and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Her CD4 cell count was 200 cells/mm3. A chest X-ray showed diffuse infiltrates. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct.

The patient presents with symptoms and signs suggestive of HIV infection. A CD4 count of fewer than 200 cells/mm3 is diagnostic of AIDS. The most common opportunistic infections in AIDS patients with CD4 counts less than 200 cells/mm3 are Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), toxoplasmosis, and cryptococcosis. The patient's symptoms and chest X-ray are consistent with PCP, which is a life-threatening infection. It is a fungal infection that is most likely visible in HIV-positive patients as they have compromised immune systems.

The initial treatment of PCP in HIV patients is through Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) which is administered orally or through veins for around 3 weeks, depending on the severity of the infection. Therefore, Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the correct answer.

Incorrect Choice: 

Option a) Azithromycin: Azithromycin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of atypical pneumonia caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae and Chlamydia pneumoniae. It is not the appropriate initial treatment for a patient with HIV infection and suspected PCP.

Option c) Fluconazole: Fluconazole is an antifungal medication used in the treatment of fungal infections such as candidiasis. It is not the appropriate initial treatment for a patient with HIV infection and suspected PCP.

Option d) Amoxicillin-clavulanate: Amoxicillin-clavulanate is an antibiotic used in the treatment of bacterial infections. It is not the appropriate initial treatment for a patient with HIV infection and suspected PCP.

questions.text: A hospital in a rural area is struggling with the proper management of biomedical waste. The hospital staff has been observed disposing of all the biomedical waste in a single bin without any segregation. This is causing concern for the hospital administration as well as the community. Upon investigation, it was found that there was no proper training provided to the staff regarding biomedical waste management. The hospital administration decides to take corrective measures and provide training to the staff on the proper segregation of biomedical waste. During the training, which of the following statements regarding the segregation of biomedical waste would be most appropriate for the hospital administration to convey to the staff?

choices.text: All types of biomedical waste should be placed in the same bin for disposal
Infectious waste should be segregated from non-infectious waste
Sharps waste should be disposed of in ordinary waste bins
Chemical waste should be segregated from pharmaceutical waste

questions.solution:
Option B is correct. 

The basic principle of biomedical waste management involves the segregation of biomedical waste at the source and the subsequent waste reduction. The process mainly involves the identification of the source, separating or segregating it from the non-infectious waste, storing the waste after collection, followed by transport, and finally, disposal.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. All types of biomedical waste should be placed in the same bin for disposal.
This option is incorrect because it goes against the basic principles of biomedical waste management, which require proper segregation of different types of waste according to their characteristics. Mixing all types of biomedical waste in the same bin can lead to cross-contamination, which can be hazardous to the health of both healthcare workers and the general public.

Option C. Sharps waste should be disposed of in ordinary waste bins.
This option is incorrect because sharps waste, such as needles, syringes, and scalpels, are potentially infectious and pose a significant risk of injury and infection to healthcare workers, waste handlers, and the general public. Sharps waste should always be disposed of in a designated sharps container to prevent accidental injury and ensure proper disposal.

Option D. Chemical waste should be segregated from pharmaceutical waste.
This option is incorrect because a pharmaceutical waste, such as expired medications, contaminated packaging, and unused medicines, can have chemical and biological hazards that require proper disposal. Pharmaceutical waste should be separated from other types of waste and disposed of through specialized disposal methods that consider environmental and health hazards. However, chemical waste, such as disinfectants and laboratory reagents, should be separately collected and disposed of as per the guidelines for hazardous waste management.

questions.text: A public health center receives a new shipment of vaccines and drugs for its immunization program. The center's medical officer in charge instructs the staff to store the vaccines and drugs appropriately. A few days later, the officer received a complaint from a community member that their child developed a fever after receiving a vaccine from the center. Upon investigation, it was found that the vaccines were stored in a storage room with no temperature monitoring system. The room had a temperature of 20°C, much higher than the recommended storage temperature range of 2-8°C. What is the most likely cause of the child's fever?

choices.text: Bacterial contamination of the vaccine during manufacturing
Incorrect administration of the vaccine by the center's staff
The vaccine's potency was affected due to incorrect storage temperature
The child was allergic to one of the vaccine's components.

questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

The vaccine's potency was affected due to incorrect storage temperature. Vaccines and drugs must be stored at the recommended temperature range to maintain their potency and effectiveness. The higher storage temperature may have reduced the potency of the vaccine, causing the child to develop a fever. It emphasizes the importance of proper storage and handling of vaccines and drugs to ensure their effectiveness and safety.

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Bacterial contamination of the vaccine during manufacturing is an unlikely cause of the child's fever in this scenario, as the complaint was related to the storage of the vaccine rather than the vaccine's manufacturing process.

Option B: Incorrect administration of the vaccine by the center's staff could be a potential cause of the child's fever, but it is not the most likely cause in this scenario as the complaint was related to the storage of the vaccine rather than the administration.

Option D: The child being allergic to one of the vaccine's components is a possibility but not the most likely cause of the child's fever in this scenario, as the complaint was related to the storage of the vaccine rather than the vaccine's components.

questions.text: A study was conducted to assess the effectiveness of a new intervention in reducing the incidence of hypertension in a population. The study produced conflicting results, with some studies reporting a significant reduction in hypertension while others reported no significant effect. Which of the following study designs would be most appropriate to combine the results of the studies and provide a summary estimate of the effect size of the intervention?
questions.solution:
Option D is correct. 

Meta-analysis would be the most appropriate study design to combine the results of the studies and provide a summary estimate of the effect size of the intervention as it is a quantitative and formal design used to assess the results of different research conducted and draw a conclusion about that.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. Cohort study is an observational study design that follows a group of individuals over time to assess the incidence of a disease or health outcome. While a cohort study can provide valuable information on the effectiveness of an intervention, it would not be appropriate to combine the results of multiple studies.

Option B. Case-control study is a type of observational study design that compares individuals with a disease to individuals without the disease to identify potential risk factors. It is not a suitable study design for combining the results of multiple studies.

Option C. Cross-sectional study is an observational study design that collects data at a single point in time to estimate the prevalence of a disease or health outcome. While cross-sectional studies can provide valuable information, they are not suitable for combining the results of multiple studies.

questions.text: A public health researcher conducted a randomized controlled trial to test the effectiveness of a new smoking cessation program in reducing the number of cigarettes smoked per day. The trial included three groups: a control group that received no intervention, a group that received a brief counselling session, and a group that received the full smoking cessation program. The researcher collected data on the number of cigarettes smoked per day at baseline and after 6 months of follow-up. The data were analysed using ANOVA. What is the appropriate use of ANOVA in this study?

choices.text: Comparing the proportion of smokers in each group
Assessing the prevalence of smoking among individuals with different demographic characteristics
Comparing the mean number of cigarettes smoked per day among individuals in each group
Assessing the impact of the intervention on quit rates among smokers

questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

In this case, ANOVA is being used to compare the means of the number of cigarettes smoked per day among the three groups. This is a continuous outcome variable, which is appropriate for ANOVA analysis. 

Incorrect choices:

Option A. It involves a comparison of proportions, which are not appropriate for ANOVA analysis. 

Option B. It involves a comparison of prevalence rates, which are not appropriate for ANOVA analysis. 

Option D. It involves a comparison of quit rates, which may also be appropriate but is not the best answer in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with a head injury after being involved in a car accident. The patient opens his eye and flexion of limb occurs on pinch. He is speaking in appropriate words. what is his GCS score?
questions.solution:
Eye opening to pain - 2
Flexion response to pain - 3

questions.text:
Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a crucial indicator of the effectiveness of a country's healthcare system. It reflects the quality of obstetric care and the accessibility of health services for pregnant women. The World Health Organization defines MMR as the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. The MMR is affected by various factors such as socioeconomic status, education, and healthcare infrastructure.
In a country, the MMR was 450 deaths per 100,000 live births in the year 2015. In the year 2020, the MMR reduced to 300 deaths per 100,000 live births. Calculate the percentage reduction in MMR during this period.
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.
To calculate the percentage reduction in MMR, we need to use the following formula:

Here, the initial value is the MMR in 2015, which is 450 deaths per 100,000 live births. The final value is the MMR in 2020, which is 300 deaths per 100,000 live births.
Substituting these values in the formula, we get:
Percentage reduction =

Therefore, the correct answer is option (a) 33.33%.
Incorrect Choice: 
(b) 50%: This is an incorrect option. It is not the correct answer to the question. The percentage reduction in MMR is 33.33%, not 50%. Therefore, this option is incorrect.
(c) 66.67%: This is an incorrect option. It is not the correct answer to the question. The percentage reduction in MMR is 33.33%, not 66.67%. Therefore, this option is incorrect.
(d) 75%: This is an incorrect option. It is not the correct answer to the question. The percentage reduction in MMR is 33.33%, not 75%. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman from a rural area in India presents to the antenatal clinic for her first check-up. During the routine investigations, she is found to have anemia. On further inquiry, the patient reveals that her diet is mainly vegetarian and lacks diversity. She also reports heavy menstrual bleeding. The healthcare worker advises her to start taking iron and folic acid tablets and counsels her on the importance of a balanced diet. Which component of the Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme is being implemented in this scenario?

choices.text: Weekly Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation for adolescent girls and pregnant women.
Introduction of fortified food products in the public distribution system.
Promotion of dietary diversity and nutrition education.
Universal salt iodization to prevent hypothyroidism.

questions.solution:
Option A is correct. 

Weekly Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) supplementation for adolescent girls and pregnant women - This is one of the key components of the Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme, which aims to provide weekly IFA supplementation to adolescent girls and pregnant women to prevent and treat anemia. This option is likely to be the correct answer because the patient is pregnant and has been advised to take iron and folic acid supplements.

Incorrect choices:

Option B. Introduction of fortified food products in the public distribution system - The Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme also includes the introduction of fortified food products, such as wheat flour and rice, in the public distribution system to improve the iron and other micronutrient content of the diet. However, this option is not applicable in the given scenario, as there is no mention of the patient receiving fortified food products.

Option C. Promotion of dietary diversity and nutrition education - Another component of the Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme is the promotion of dietary diversity and nutrition education to ensure that people consume a balanced diet that includes iron-rich foods. This option is also relevant to the given scenario, as the healthcare worker has counseled the patient on the importance of a balanced diet. However, the immediate action taken by the healthcare worker was to introduce iron and folic acid supplements in the form of tablets. Therefore, option C is an incorrect choice.

Option D. Universal salt iodization to prevent hypothyroidism - it is not addressed by the Anemia Mukt Bharat Programme. This option is, therefore, not relevant to the given scenario.

questions.text: A 15 year old male presented to the OPD with complains of high fever, headache, tremors and stiff neck 10 days after returning from his trip to Australia. He recalls of having lots of mosquito bites during his travel. The blood reports confirmed Japanese encephalitis as the diagnosis. Which of the following is the Amplifier host in Japanese encephalitis?
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis:

  • Cause: Group-B Arbovirus.
  • Vector : Culex triteniorhynchus[ MC in India ].
  • Birds are natural hosts: pond herons, cattle egrets, poultry & duck.
  • Pigs are ‘Amplifier hosts’: pigs themselves do not manifest overt symptoms but circulate the virus.
  • Cattle & buffaloes are ‘mosquito attractants’: infected but not the natural hosts of JE virus.
  • Horses are only domestic animals which show signs of encephalitis.
  • Man is an ‘Incidental dead end host’. Man to man transmission is not seen 85% cases occur in children <15 years of age.
  • I.P - 5-15 Days.
  • Vaccines - Live strain : SA-14-14-2 ; Killed strain : Nakayama, Beijing P3 [earlier].

questions.text: In a community, the range of systolic blood pressure readings among adults is between 90-190 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate measure of central tendency to represent this data?
questions.solution:
Option B is correct. 

The range of systolic blood pressure readings among adults in the community is between 90-190 mmHg. The range is a measure of dispersion, not a central tendency. The mean is affected by extreme values; in this case, extreme values (e.g., 90 or 190 mmHg) may be present. The mode may not be useful because there may not be a single value that appears more frequently than others. Therefore, the most appropriate measure of central tendency to represent this data is the median, which is the middle value when the readings are arranged in ascending or descending order.

Incorrect choices:

Option A. The mean can be defined as the measure of central tendency where the average value of a data set is represented. It is calculated by adding all the values in the set and dividing by the number of values. However, the mean is not appropriate to represent this data because it is sensitive to extreme values. In this case, the range of systolic blood pressure readings among adults is wide, and extreme values may be present. These extreme values can significantly affect the mean, resulting in a misleading representation of the data.

Option C. The mode is a measure of central tendency that represents the most frequent value in a set of data. However, in this case, there may not be a single value that appears more frequently than others. The range of systolic blood pressure readings among adults is wide, and the readings may be distributed evenly, making it difficult to determine a mode.

Option D. The standard deviation is a measure of dispersion representing the degree of variation or spread of a data set from the mean. It is not appropriate to represent this data as it provides information about the spread of the data but not about its central tendency. Additionally, calculating the standard deviation requires calculating the mean first, which may be affected by extreme values.

questions.text: In a rural village in a developing country, a sudden outbreak of diarrhoea has affected many residents; however, none of the cases reported bloody diarrhoea. After investigating, the public health officials found that the outbreak’s source was contaminated drinking water. The water source was a nearby well, which had become contaminated with faecal matter due to poor sanitation practices in the village. The officials immediately took action to provide clean water to the affected population and educated them on the importance of proper sanitation and hygiene practices. Upon inspection of the contaminated water source, it was observed that the causative agent was a bacterium. Which of the following waterborne diseases could have caused the village’s diarrhoea outbreak?
questions.solution:
Option C is correct. 

  • Cholera, caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, is characterized by severe diarrhoea, vomiting, and dehydration. It is typically spread through contaminated water or food, particularly in areas with poor sanitation. 
  • In the case described above, where there is a sudden break of diarrhoea, cholera is likely to cause an outbreak as the symptoms described match the typical presentation of cholera. It is known that common cholera strains don’t cause bloody stool or diarrhoea, and since there is no reported case of bloody diarrhoea in the village, Cholera is the correct choice. 

Incorrect choices:

Option A: Giardiasis caused by the protozoan parasite Giardia lamblia shows symptoms of giardiasis typically include diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, bloating, and gas. It can be transmitted through contaminated water, particularly in areas with poor sanitation. Although less common, giardiasis is also known to cause bloody stool in certain cases. Since giardiasis is a protozoan disease and may cause bloody stool sometimes, it is an incorrect choice.

Option B: Shigellosis is a bacterial infection usually caused due to contaminated water or raw foods. The causative agent of shigellosis is the bacteria Shigella. Symptoms include bloody diarrhoea, stomach pain, fever, etc. Since it is a bacterial infection that results in bloody diarrhoea, it is an incorrect choice.

Option D: Amoebic dysentery, caused by the protozoan parasite Entamoeba histolytica, is one of the common waterborne diseases that can be transmitted through contaminated water. It is characterized by inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, which most of the time results in bloody diarrhoea. Symptoms include diarrhoea, bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and fever. Since amoebic dysentery is a protozoan disease and can cause bloody diarrhea, it is not the correct choice.
